I was expecting a lot from Transistor, I thought “wow, it is a sci-fi Hades with a complex story and an innovative combat system featuring tactical elements, would be great thing to play while waiting for Hades 2”.  Well, it is not just not it, unfortunately it’s not a good game at all in my opinion.

If you’ve been captivated by visual style and brilliant soundtrack - well, that’s because these are the best parts of the game. Narration and voice acting in general is top notch as well. Everything else is unfortunately underwhelming.

Combat system is a mix of real time battle with tactical pause option. Protagonist moves very slowly to the point where you can’t evade a shot fired from across the map, all strikes have long startup and even worse recovery, this makes it feel sluggish. Acting during tactical pause imposes a cooldown where you can’t do anything, which hurts especially since the basic movement is so poor. This makes both modes just not fun… I ended up not using tactical mode at all until later in the game I was able to assemble a combination of functions to one-shot anything during the pause - this actually added to my frustrations since it eliminated any difficulty. The idea of functions changing properties depending on their use seems brilliant at first, but I felt some combinations were much better than others and theoretical variety of approaches just didn’t work for me.

Story is slow as well. Mystery is sustained by characters purposefully not telling you what they know. You’re driven forward by curiosity, you gradually uncover new elements. The disappointing part is that elements you uncover turn out to be mostly irrelevant and promise of answers - unfulfilled. Often you just get another line of cryptic dialog and a next checkpoint. I also struggled to develop a connection with Red as she does not speak. This is a purposeful choice of authors and I respect it, but her motivations or role in the grand scheme of things are not clear, you just don’t know her. She is portrayed as a victim you’re supposed to sympathise to, but that’s about it, for me that wasn’t enough.

The city aesthetically looks great, it is a significant part of the story and the world, the problem is it fails to develop properly. You visit different parts of the city (some of them - multiple times) and yet they all look the same. You move from one tiny arena where you fight generic faceless enemies to another, the story explains that you’re somewhere else but you don’t feel it. 

The game also suffers from disjointed elements - you get a hideout where you have to do missions, like time attacks. Why? There is no incentive to play these (especially considering the fact that the core gameplay loop is just not fun) or explanation why these are important. Limiters too - all seem like attempts to extend gameplay artificially.

I’m a completionist and yet I dropped the game half way. I only picked it up recently (it runs great on Steam Deck which I took on a flight), but as soon as the plot actually started developing and something interesting began happening - the game ended… so you can add underwhelming ending to the list of other underwhelming things this game offers.

Very sad.

I tried to get into this game when it came out but was not a fan of the turn-based beat-em-up mashup. I also had problems running the game at resolutions above 1080p (Still is a problem, though technically its on purpose as everything is hand-drawn and then mastered @ 1080p). This was before refunds were really a thing on Steam, and I kinda digged the soundtrack, so I let Transistor sit there in my library. 

Come 2023, close to a decade later, I decided on a whim to boot the game up on my Steam Deck. And the game finally clicked for me. Absolutely no problems running the game on Deck (as the screen is only 800p) and the Linux port is superb, bar a few things that I touch upon in my report on [url=https://www.protondb.com/app/237930] ProtonDB. [/url]

Gameplay-wise the game is still a little clunky (I kinda already hate turn based games for the most part), but you need to push through and attempt to understand the clunkiness to actually get anything out of this game. Finding out new combinations of abilities as you progress through the game is fun and rewarding if you take the time to get out of your comfort zone, with the added reward of extra lore for mixing up your abilities. I think I would've liked this game more the first time I tried it years ago if the tutorial was more upfront about how you probably should play the game. It is best practice to never fully deplete the Turn() bar (unless you are about to end the fight), otherwise you will be stuck in the horrible debuff status of "Recharging", where you become a headless chicken attempting to remove a bunch of ants crawling up your legs. Not sure why the devs just didn't either A. have some sort of punishment other than complete revokation of player agency when fully depleting the Turn() bar or B. make the narrator say something like, "You're really living on the edge here, maybe hold off on exhausting me" or something of that nature to lead the player away from doing that consistently. I don't think it was obvious that Turn() bar recharge time was proportional to how much you used it, when I first played the game this really caught me out and was quite frustrating.

Just about everything else other than that is well thought out, from the lore within the character interactions and mini biographys to the general cohesion of the game thematically. Knowing more about programming now than I did then I can see a lot of little tongue and cheek jokes scattered throughout the game, and its all very endearing. Hopefully when I get to playing Hades at least some of the DNA from Transistor is in there.

Title: "Transistor: A Melodic Elegy to the Digital World"

In the dimly lit corridors of the digital realm, "Transistor" emerges as a hauntingly beautiful elegy, where every pixel whispers secrets and every line of code hums a mournful tune. It's a masterpiece of storytelling and aesthetics that leaves an indelible mark on your soul.

The first thing that strikes you is the artistry that permeates every inch of this virtual cityscape. The juxtaposition of a neon-lit dystopia against the ethereal glow of the "Transistor" itself creates an atmosphere that's both chilling and captivating. It's a world that seems to exist in the twilight of a dream, where the line between reality and illusion blurs.

And then there's the music, a hauntingly evocative soundtrack that's the heart and soul of the game. The humming, mournful notes of Red's voice as she wields the Transistor as a weapon is both mesmerizing and melancholic. It's as if the game itself is pouring its emotions into your ears, a somber serenade that echoes through the digital void.

The narrative is a poignant dance between the characters, their past, and the haunting uncertainty of the future. Red, a singer who's lost her voice, and the Transistor, a sentient weapon housing the consciousness of a fallen friend, form a duo that tugs at your heartstrings with every word they exchange. Their journey through the fractured city is a tale of sacrifice, redemption, and the profound connection between humans and machines.

The combat mechanics are a symphony of strategy and finesse. As Red wields the Transistor in real-time or activates its tactical functions in a pause-and-plan mode, you feel a sense of empowerment amidst the digital chaos. It's a dance of power and vulnerability, much like the characters themselves.

But perhaps what lingers the most is the bittersweet beauty of the game's themes. "Transistor" explores the price of progress, the consequences of our choices, and the inevitability of loss. It's a reminder that even in a world of artificiality, the most human emotions persist.

In conclusion, "Transistor" is a work of digital art that resonates deeply with those who venture into its enigmatic world. It's a solemn, bittersweet beauty, a digital requiem that leaves you haunted by its elegance and entranced by its narrative. It's a reminder that even in the realm of ones and zeros, the human experience finds a way to shine through, and it's nothing short of mesmerizing.

i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

transistor is an action-rpg developed and published by supergiant games. it is their second game, after 2012's bastion, and their first self-published title. it was released in 2014 for PS4 and PC, while a mobile port came in 2015 and a nintendo switch port arrived in 2018. supergiant began concept work throughout 2011 as they wrapped up development for bastion, eventually starting work full-time on transistor in september 2012, a few months after bastion released. after having a team of seven people working on bastion, supergiant upped their team size to twelve people for transistor. 

transistor features both real-time and frozen turn-based style that utilizes a planning mode beforehand. as you progress through the game you earn new 'functions,' which act as abilities and can be further used to augment other functions and/or give passive effects during battle. there's a ton of combinations which allows for a great amount of customization and options to fit different playstyles. i really enjoy the flexibility and the idea that experimentation is encouraged. combat isn't simplistic and at the same time it isn't over difficult or convoluted. i like how it has similarities to bastion, but sets itself apart enough and shows that it is just as good if not better in it's own right. it does story-telling and worldbuilding similarly to bastion, but again is different enough to not feel derivative despite being similarly linear. one review i read called the plot "interestingly deep yet frustratingly vague" and that is a really good way to describe the story/plot.

transistor can routinely be found for 80 or 85% off, making it only two or three dollars which is an insane value for this, even if it's biggest flaw (in my opinion) is how short the completion experience is compared to bastion (for reference, i spent over 25 hours completing bastion and spent 22 hours completing transistor). i am extremely excited to eventually getting around to completing pyre before diving in to hades fully, ideally before hades 2 comes out. i definitely recommend wish-listing and waiting to buy transistor on sale if you're even slightly interested in this game.

I’m a sci fi fan, but the transhumanist sci fi subgenre is not my thing; I found this game just a [i]little[/i] creepy (which I’m sure was the point). Supergiant is known for its distinctive art style, and here it does a phenomenal job of conveying the game’s atmosphere: beautiful and isolating and melancholy – but without an over-reliance on the color gray. True, as the game progresses, white overtakes the city, but the changing color palette really helps convey the story.

[i]Transistor[/i]’s story is straightforward and linear, and, honestly, I found it rather weak; it relied a little too much on an air of mystery without fully delivering. However, the relationship between the Transistor (voiced by the immensely talented Logan Cunningham) and Red was poignant, so I can forgive the storyline.

I struggled with the gameplay controls and the cadence of combat. Unlike [i]Bastion[/i]’s simple controls or [i]Hades[/i]’s more complex ones, both which can be mapped to one’s preferences and then forgotten about, if you lose a Function in [i]Transistor[/i], the gameplay controls change. I’m sure this was in service to the multiplicity of ways to combine Functions, but I found it frustrating. 

The game provides a Sandbox for experimenting with ways to combine Functions, but even so, as a casual gamer, I found it difficult to figure out which ones synergized well together. Unlike in [i]Bastion[/i], levels are not designed to show off a Function’s best uses, and unlike in [i]Hades[/i], it felt like there were a lot fewer effective synergy options.

Ultimately, I consulted a combat guide. If you’re a casual gamer like me, I urge you to look up a combat guide to save yourself a lot of frustration.

The combat itself: I found the cadence of [i]pause, take your turn, then watch it play out in real time[/i] jarring and difficult to get used to. And, frankly, frustrating, when I couldn’t avoid a hit (and I took many). I wished more than once for [i]Bastion[/i]’s No Sweat Mode or [i]Hades[/i]’s God Mode.

Yet I got to the end of the story and couldn’t stop thinking about it. I ended up choosing to Recourse() through the story again despite all my frustrations with the combat and the disquiet the game’s atmosphere caused me. So I give [i]Transistor[/i] a thumbs up.

TLDR 8.5/10: Unpolished in places, but contains such an attention to detail and heart that none of that feels like it matters. Great visuals and OST as well as a beautiful story.

[Spoilers Ahead]

When playing through Transistor, for the first half of the game I felt like I didn't *get* it. The story felt bland, the talking sword would not shut up, and the gameplay felt clunky, despite the joy of clearing an entire room with a successful turn(). I liked the art style and music, but with Supergiant and Darren Korb (as well as featuring the ever-talented Ashley Barrett on vocals), that came as little surprise. I wanted to be invested in the world, I really did, but then around halfway through, it clicked. 

I was thinking of it like Hades, not, well, Transistor.

Transistor's point isn't the grandeur of the story, its not the minute backstory of side characters mentioned once. It's Red and her...husband? Around the section leading up to the Spine boss fight, every single thing I felt confused about locked into place and made me appreciate the game with new eyes. Hades, while dealing with the underworld and family trauma, was still genuinely optimistic. Transistor is not that. The world is dystopic, dying. The supposed main villains are equally out of control as you are. And yet, Transistor shows that if anything else, it is a game about the fierce love that Red and her husband share.
Her husband is constantly talking both as a way to fill the silence left by Red's stolen voice, but as a proof that "You're still there, and I'm still here." And Red herself is equally invested, using a terminal to tell her delirious husband that she will "find what is doing this to you and break its heart." 

The world doesn't matter. The Camerata doesn't matter. The bosses don't matter. The story is not about any grand scheme, it's about how when literally nothing else is left, love persists. And I think that's damn beautiful. 

So to all those people like me who love Hades to bits, know that Transistor is not the same type of game, even though it seems like it. Transistor doesn't have the polish, the detail, the sheer mass of Hades. What is does have, is far more abstract, and I would argue far more transient.

136842405.review:
The saddest thumbs down I've ever given. 

It's a studio I love and a probably one of the most aesthetically pleasing games I've ever played. It's gorgeous and I adore the sound track. 

Oh boy, where to start. So going in, I assumed it was going to be Bastion 2.0, and I was pleasantly surprised to find out that it wasn't. Transistor is weird with a capital W. You continuously move from point A to B with some flavor text to inspect. Battles happen in arenas where you use a combination of clunky and slow abilities, and then those abilities sped up in a turn based, planning format. 

At the onset, I loved the exploratory nature of it. It's different than anything I've experienced and there were ideas that had promise here. The game's biggest sin is the inability to build on those ideas in true RPG format. The game scales sideways. You get variety upon variety with slight variation as you level up. Different abilities with different passives you collect. And while that might sound like exactly what you want, it's really not. 

The game play is thin with essentially nothing changing as you progress, only variety of choices mounting. Each ability caps at two passives attached, and those aren't game changing. While it's nice to have four intrinsic passive abilities as you go, they aren't game changing. The construction of combat makes your abilities flavor with your basic strategy and rhythm you establish being 99% of the execution. It fundamentally lacks any sense of progression or deepening. Once you establish how you like to play, then bam, that's it. (And the game shows you global player pick rates. Spoiler: People play in a very similar way because it's easy).

The game tries to encourage you vary it up with some lore unlocks, but even that is kind of sad. It literally requires you to use abilities once. Even then, it's not a good system by player engagement alone. Half the people who started the game have used five abilities to their fullest. Five. You can equip four at once. Either the core game play feature is so uncompelling that people don't adequately explore it, or people lose engagement so fast that they give up before getting there. 

And let's go further into that. The unlocks are related to level and story progression. You are on the rails with only a tiny hub that feels like a bonus world that lets you do trials for a tiny sliver of experience. It doesn't feel there is anything to explore or any reward for that. 

And if you're going to put us on rails, then it needs to be an exciting journey. The story is. . . very barebones. You're given the barest amount of plot to get you going then it's ready set go. Bad guy tried to kill you last night. Go kill him. There isn't enough to be compelling, and in the biggest sin of all: Your sword is boring. That sword on the artwork is a character and your chatty companion that makes up 95% of all dialogue, and he's surprisingly boring. If you get nothing else out of Supergiant games, it's not boring writing. 

Overall

Sadness. I appreciate the attempts at creativity and adventure in game design, but no level of aesthetic appeal can carry this. The vast number of positive reviews is for the looks and music; I assure you. For that, I too am happy this exists. But like, I'd never recommend it. 5/10

Great top-down "strategy/turn based-ish" game, with an interesting, albeit slightly convoluted story.

Visuals-wise, the game has it's own style, which is different from Supergiant Games' previous title (Bastion). You're in a futuristic city, where something has gone wrong.

Combat takes the form of battles, the playing field being limited by borders. You can use your spells "in real time", or set up a planning phase, where your character will queue up actions (each spell and action taking a certain amount of a "time" resource during the planning phase).
I would recommend trying out new spells and combinations, as I believe it's one of the main "fun" aspects of the game.

Story-wise, your character doesn't talk, somebody else does the narration. There also isn't a lot of "direct" lore exposition, you sort of discover everything by yourself, although you can miss a lot of details.

The OST is amazing, though weirdly enough, you don't get to hear the main "vocal" songs a lot.

It would take you about 3-5 hours to beat this game, depending on how quickly you progress through the story.

134037656.review:
[h1]Red & A Transistor [/h1]
Basic premise/Story

From developer studio, Supergiant Games. And returning composer Darren Korb. Comes with an all-new game from the studio called Transistor. Where you follow a young female protagonist by the name of Red. Who has lost her voice and finds herself alone with a greatsword nearby who can communicate with her. And together the duo will need to work alongside one another as they combat the robotic enemies called the Process. Discover what has befallen their city, how to recover her voice, and unravel the mystery of the Process.

[h1]Function, Evade, Attack, Repeat [/h1]
Unique Gameplay

There’s something quite remarkable about playing another Supergiant game. Not only are you treated with a gorgeous visual style along with a different plot from Bastion. But the gameplay and soundtrack is also something entirely new. Its refreshing, bold and tackles new territory. For combat it’s more tactical and you can attack in real-time or use a special mode called “Turn()” that allows the player to create a zone where enemies are frozen and you can queue attacks and configure your direction to attack one or multiple enemies. 

It took a bit of handling, but I found the process similar to how the old fallout CRPGs were done. You have an action bar and this represents how many actions you can do. Any movement, evasion, and abilities used will decrease the bar. So plan carefully. 

I found the feature very strategic in that there are a multitude of ways to attack your enemies, with backstabs rewarding you with more damage. And equipping different skills. The game gives you new abilities to choose from as you level up and I found this mechanic pretty nifty since you can choose which skills you want for your build and more. 

Making the combat fresh and enjoyable since I could switch different skills, augment them, grant different effects, and even passive skills as well. There is a limit though, so don’t expect to be smart and think you can be overpowered from the start. You gotta work for it. 

Aside from the combat. There are plenty of interaction points in the game to gently feed you lore and I found these points enjoyable and not sparse. Just enough to hold your interest, but not spammed in every zone to the extent of hitting an upper limit. Each piece of information given from terminals is intriguing enough to enrich the world-building, and I loved that. The narrator, this time speaking from your sword is excellent and I have no complaints about his soothing voice throughout the game. 

[h1]The Voices in the Machine [/h1]
Final thoughts/Ruminations

Throughout my playthrough, I didn’t experience any bugs or crashes. The game played pretty well, with no egregious slowdown. Despite the praise, I’ve given to the game above. I did wish there were more tutorials in the game or at least a dedicated tutorial settings page where you refresh your memory on new and old features. And the beginning of the game could be a bit of a struggle for newcomers since there is no exposition given right at the start. You jump right into the game and have to piece the narrative yourself. This isn’t a problem for me, but for others, I feel it could’ve been tweaked a bit more to provide some context on the world and to make the players become invested in Red’s character in the beginning. Just a minor critique. 

Beyond that, I feel the game is a unique take on a different theme the developers wanted to tackle than their previous work. I was impressed at how the beginning, middle, and end finally coalesced and the themes demonstrated here I feel were executed strongly. I rarely see this theme in other video games. And I could only recall one film that displays the theme in a similar vein. But I won’t say anymore due to spoilers. You’ll have to play the game to find out. Just know I found the story and ending to be very well done. I had an enjoyable experience throughout my playthrough. From the tight combat to the fitting electronic post-rock soundtrack lends itself well to the cyberpunk setting. It is a solid new game after Bastion’s original release. And I can’t believe it took me years before I finally got around to it. If you’re hungry for more Supergiant games. Don’t miss out on Transistor.

This game is absolutely gorgeous, the 2d art cutscenes and the isometric style of the game really complement each other, the music is fantastic as well! The story is fun and interesting even though it's a simple "revenge" plot, the overall presentation is beautiful, and the characters are cool, I love both Red and Transistor even though one of these characters doesn't even speak.

It has really fun combat that mixes action combat with real-time strategy in a unique way, I found the strategy part to be really fun, but it falls short when it comes to the the action combat, because the enemies are so fast, you'll have a pretty tough time waiting for your turn meter to fill up, especially considering most abilites are locked while you recover your turn. The most frustrating part of the combat is that when you lose all your health instead of dying and restarting the encounter, you instead lose some of your abilities and have to continue the fight without them, and you don't get them until a couple of encounters later, making it annoying having to play with suboptimal abilities because of one fuck-up

Speaking of abilities, the upgrade system in this game is really cool, you can have up to 4 active and 4 passive abilities (or functions as the game calls them), and up to 2 upgrades for each active function, the really interesting part is that every function you unlock can be fitted into any slot, making a variety of interesting builds; for example, there is a function called Help(), when it's active it allows you to summon a dog companion which has turns of its own (if you slot Split() into its upgrade slot, you get two dogs!), when it's an upgrade slot it has a chance to prevent enemies from respawning, if it's in the passive slot, it gives you a chance to replace all your active functions with one super powerful function that deals massive damage, every turn. There are about 20 functions that you gradually unlock throughout the game. However, in challenge rooms, you don't have all your unlocked functions, and you have curated functions for each one, this made some of them really frustrating to clear, especially when they give you functions you haven't unlocked yet, and you have no idea how to use them, as there is no inventory menu to check what they do.


Despite my grievances with the game, I would say this is overall an 8/10 game! It impressed me in a few areas I wasn't expecting and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun game.

The oft-overlooked second game by Supergiant Games, Transistor deserves more attention than it gets. I understand why it's so often ignored: Bastion was a phenomenal debut, and these days who wants to talk about anything but Hades, but Transistor happened in between those two and deserves more credit (that's true of Pyre too, but it was less my speed).

Does the gameplay always work? Frankly, no, often it's a bit clunky, and the balance is hilariously busted, with some builds being borderline impossible, while others trivialise >95% of all combat. Considering how intuitive and engaging both Hades and Bastion are, this is something of a issue for Transistor, but in my personal opinion, it's pretty much the only one.

Even now, eight years after release, it looks absolutely gorgeous, the soundtrack (by the inimitable Darren Korb) is positively genius, and the narrative still stands out as one of my favourite in all of gaming. In particular, Transistor messes around with player agency in ways that to this day I have not found matched anywhere else - more specifically, it denies the player agency and in so doing, empowers the protagonist, Red.

I don't want to say too much about the events of the game, as I believe Transistor is best experienced without too much knowledge, but that note is worth hitting upon: there will be moments when you don't have even the illusion of choice, and those moments are because the protagonist is making the choice for herself - the player is merely there to see her safely through her story.

In short, I love it. 

10/10

127888868.review:
I have great respect for Supergiant and believe their games to be labors of love from a genuinely talented team. That's why it pains me to not recommend Transistor, no matter how much I REALLY wanted to like it.

Getting the good out of the way quickly, Transistor looks and sounds amazing just like every other Supergiant game. The art is excellent, the voice acting is great, and the music is crisp and somber. The artistic direction in the game is top notch.

The ideas behind the gameplay are extremely interesting. I really enjoyed how much customization was crammed into so few buttons and it really felt like the game was created with the intent to let a variety of playstyles be fun and effective.

That's it for the good. Now for the bad. The gameplay does a great job hooking the player in the beginning but it becomes clear that there's virtually nothing here beyond an idea. Combat is clunky, the balance between abilities/upgrades is terrible, you are forced to play in small areas with a ton of visual and physical clutter, information is not accurately relayed to the player (especially when using the game's primary gimmick, the Turn() function), and the enemies lean more towards irritating than actually challenging. Even worse, a few enemies/encounters feel genuinely unfair because of how stiffly you control and how "dodging" some attacks is only possible when using the "optional" Jaunt() (dodge roll/dash) or standing behind breakable cover. Despite this unfairness, the game is generally very easy.

Exploration is nearly non-present. There are some optional things to take a look at or optional challenges right off the beaten path but the game is essentially just a series of rectangular rooms with or without enemies one after another. It's all dressed up well and the city environment is beautiful but any sense of wonder is stifled by your limited traversal options. There are also no puzzles to speak of, making the game little more than walking from room to room triggering encounters.

The visual design of the enemies does not hold up to the art direction everywhere else. There is nothing inherently wrong with them, but they are bland and uninteresting compared to everything else around you. This might be alleviated if there were any interesting characters to interact with but there is very little dialogue or proximity to anything actually alive/sentient save for the "soul" of the character in your sword. I liked listening to my sword speak (and he speaks somewhat incessantly) and he may have been one of the only things that compelled me to complete the game.

Speaking of completion, this is an approximately 4 hour game. Nothing wrong with something short and sweet but something about the brevity and flatness of the experience screams "half-baked" to me. There is a story beat where you will realize that rather than just getting started you are closer to 75% done with the game. I am still unsure if this was meant to be subversive or if Supergiant ran out of time or budget but i'm leaning towards the latter.

I know some people like the story and even cried when they played. I am not one of those people. I enjoyed the characterization between the player character and the voice in her sword but my motivation to learn more about them slowly died as I learned how underdeveloped the story and the setting was. Frankly, I think the story is contrived, rushed, and at times nonsensical. The ending, which should have been poignant, wound up having no effect on me. The drama of the acting and the music were nearly comedic in juxtaposition with how baffingly unengaging each story beat was. I genuinely expected much, much better.

Overall, Transistor is deeply forgettable. It has all of the Supergiant charm and beauty on a surface level but it fails to meaningfully deliver in the end because it feels plain unfinished and, at times, uninspired. I would skip this game unless you are committed to playing through everything developed by Supergiant.

I wish steam had a middle of the road option again

Overall, I do like this game, but I voted it down because if you're reading through negative reviews your probably wanting to find a more rounded opinion of the game. It's a pretty middle of the road game gameplay and story wise, and is worth getting on sale perhaps to kill a day or weekend.

PROS:
- as always, the aesthetics are nailed by supergiant. Music, art, tone, everything is so beautiful
- highly customizable combat system which is fun to tinker with, but..
CONS: 
- the combat system, though in theory should be fun, in actual execution, is a bit tedious and dull. You get to have 4 attacks mapped to ABXY. You slot in your attacks. Each attack also functions as an upgrade to another attack, or as a passive buff (for example a cloak functions as a toggle ability when mapped to ABXY, but when used as an upgrade provides cloak to be triggered with the attack). This sounds awesome, but the combat system relies on a freeze frame, queue up attacks, and then hit execute method. You will wish you were running around button mashing and enjoying your cool customizable arsenal, but instead you just wind up watching it do it for you. Is is satisfying to plan out your stuff ahead of time? Maybe, but the drawback is that you basically watch it do the fun stuff for you.
- despite how much people love the story, I will argue the story here is very dull, cliche, and predictable. You follow the story of two lovers with no context as to why they are lovers. You just are supposed to root for them I guess? There's an ending I won't spoil, but I found that to be trite as well. I will give the story credit in one way, which is the tone of it is really nailed. The universe seems really interesting. There's a lot of lore going on here. But the characters themselves were begging me to relate to them, when they gave me no real reason to. Still, some people may love the story and the ending and really care for the protagonists; I just am not one of them and I'm sure others will feel the same way that it's a bit hamfisted.

And this may be a pro or a con depending on your perspective, but the game is short. You can finish it in 6 hours without really trying to speedrun or anything. I personally like this in a sea of 20+ hour games in my backlog, as I'm more likely to play a game these days if it's shorter. However, it may not be worth the price.

So the verdict? I doubt anyone buying this will regret it, as there's obviously a lot of care that went into this game, and it's not unplayable or anything like that. Most people will like it, others will love it, and a few will just kinda go "eh" at it. If anyone does hate it, no doubt it's the combat system. 

(my play time doesn't reflect the game, I have it on switch and finished it there)

121991002.review:
As much as I can appreciate this game and would love to love it, I can't say I'd actually recommend Transistor.

TL;DR: Well put together game with great aesthetics and interesting ideas, but the gameplay design takes most of the ideas in the wrong direction, fighting against the player instead of working with them.

Supergiant went on to fix pretty much all of these issues in Hades though, so I'd love to see them take another shot at this game's combat system with their new approach!

---

I'd probably have given this a strong positive review if I finished it back when i purchased it in 2014, or if i was a story-first gamer, but after playing Hades & a replay of Bastion I feel that Transistor's gameplay is constantly fighting against the player by comparison. This game's 2nd boss has a lower completion rate than the FINAL boss of any other Supergiant game, and after playing this through today I can see why nearly 70% of people decided to put this game down less than halfway through.

- Picking up enemy "Cells" to finish them off feels like a mechanic that was put in place as a bandaid to keep long range builds in-check. It's not a bad idea, but nothing is done with it so it adds nothing to the game. Hades does this much better with its "Cast" system. Not a huge fault on its own, but this is the first of many mechanics that feel designed to work against the player instead of for them.

- The game has a habit of disabling its own systems, rather than leaning into them like Hades does. The Cells mentioned above are a good example. It would be great to have more synergies like perk that makes Cells explode, giving you some extra bonuses on being picked up, but instead we have a perk that gives skills a chance to disable the Cell system. Waste of potential.

- Other good examples of this are the crowd control mechanics used by enemies:

One disables your ability to use Turn() while standing in the area, completely disrupting the flow of combat and getting you killed if you tried to enter Turn() without realizing and end up standing there. Why does it not just apply a penalty to the amount of time skills consume while in Turn() mode instead of disabling your inputs? This enemy ability makes me feel stupid as a player for whiffing a bunch of Turn() attempts, rather than feeling like I used or failed to use my strategies to overcome an obstacle.

Another blocks out random chunks of the screen. The goal is to memorize the enemy locations, either by spamming Move & Undo to scout the area, or spamming Pause & Unpause to view a snapshot of it. I'm not sure which one of these was the "intended" one because both are so obnoxious to do that whichever one you stumble upon first is probably going to have you react with "that's probably not how you are supposed to do that, but it works".

Another blocks out your camera with a snapshot. I'm okay with a game having a only a few different types of enemies, but that smaller number comes with an expectation of better and more meaningful mechanics than this, not filling 20% of the very limited slots with different variations of "now you can't see the game".

These enemy designs are annoying, not engaging. They would probably draw a lot more criticism if this game was released today instead of in 2014.

- Another point on disabling its own systems; Losing abilities to save you from death sounds like a neat way to force players to change their setup on paper, but in practice it just encourages a bunch of unfun gameplay patterns to try and circumvent it. Restarting combat encounters, using expensive scapegoat abilities to burn first, or accepting your fate and wasting 5 minutes in a menu re-allocating a slightly weaker version of your existing build are all poor outcomes.

- Despite this, the game balance completely breaks in half against the power of the status effect that turns enemies into allies. You can permanently lock down every single non-boss encounter in the game like this with such a low amount of investment and effort that it feels more like cheating than coming up with a clever combo. Encounters with large single enemies may as well not exist because of this, because they are unable to take any actions for the entire battle.

- Having nothing available to do between Turns() by default really hurts the pace of combat. While you are not truly 'forced' to use Jaunt() or a Jaunt() supported skill, the game design feels like it was built with a mindset of "of course they are using Jaunt()". This game is begging for a default attack that you can use to recharge your turn faster, like in Final Fantasy 7 Remake.

- Interfaces are clunky and information is spread across multiple screens in ways that force you to have to flick back and forth in menus. Information is not present when you need it, like being given a pre-made loadout for a trial with seemingly no way to check what the loadout's skills actually do.

- Skills frequently do less damage than they say they will due to things like enemies changing position or orientation. I personally think the game should have fudged the hitboxes behind the scenes in order to keep the damage reports honest and adjust the balance accordingly, instead of surprising the player with a lethal attack from an enemy that was expected to die.

- Enemy attacks are extremely unforgiving in their timing, but not in an engaging way like Sekiro or Devil May Cry. The way this game is balanced leads to one of the more extreme cases of "abuse or be abused" that I've seen in a game, but not in an exciting way.

- Limiters rewarding extra EXP while including a limiter that reduces your Memory feels like another wasted opportunity, and seems like it is designed backwards. I would rather gain increased Memory instead of EXP, giving me increased customization options to handle the increased threat.

- I don't have a problem with any of the individual effects from the Limiters, but the way they combine ends up encouraging you to use builds that are truly balance shattering. This would be fine if these builds were still interesting to use, but instead enemies are either deleted instantly or permanently disabled from status effects.

- Annoying environmental damage sometimes happens before combat, adding nothing to the game except a click of the reset button so you can climb the staircase properly this time. This is another thing that makes me feel like a stupid gamer being punished for taking a hit from a random non-combat wall-tentacle. I'm not sure where they were finding the fun when designing these sections. It's a relatively minor thing, but when you experience it alongside everything previously listed it sticks out as another moment that makes you ask "Why did they design it like this?"

- The final boss is extremely polarizing towards different builds. Many builds suffer horribly due to the "mechanic". 4x Defense passives with Cull() + Mask() backstab walks through the fight like it's a tutorial. Not very engaging regardless of which side you end up on here. As cool as the idea of these types of fights are, this one is all style and no substance when it comes to being an engaging boss fight.

This boss mechanic mechanic needs to be thought out in a more interactive way in order to work properly, rather than giving up on the idea of being an action hybrid game. This boss design goes fully into the turn based aspect of this game, but it is a very poorly designed turn based battle. Action gamers will be disappointed that the game has given up on one half of its promise, and turn based gamers will be disappointed at the lackluster mechanics.

With all of these things combined together into the same game, the gameplay systems feel like they have been kneecapped by a design approach that asks "How do we make sure this isn't too strong" instead of the Hades approach of "how do we make sure this is fun to use, and works with other systems". I love Supergiant, but I can't bring myself to love Transistor.

I don't often review games on steam, but I will post a review for this one. I remember when I first saw this, I scrolled by it multiple times on my steam page before finally deciding to get it and play it, and I'm so glad I did. Even after Hades and Pyre, this is still my favorite game by Supergiant- and considering how phenomenal Hades and Pyre are, and how much I love those two games, that's extremely high praise in my book. 

The combat is unique and refreshing- it's turn based, and was a learning curve for me when I first started playing, but once I got the hang of it, there was something so satisfying about destroying the Process bit by bit. The system of 'death' is one that is also really well done- you don't die, but instead, you lose one of your powers for a battle or two. It makes those battles harder, and it really feels like a consequence. It's also far less frustrating than dying immediately and having to do a battle over and over again, which I appreciate a ton.

Of course, another huge part of this game is the immersive nature of the world around you sucks you into a story rich with tiny details that, if you pay attention, have so much meaning. Telling me that a passage way down to another platform has 36 steps has no impact on the gameplay, but it is actually those tiny details that make the world draw me in more. There's so many layers, packaged in a way that's satisfying to the brain. Not only that, but the characters are unbelievably powerful in helping to tell the narrative too- the voice actors in this game do such an incredible job of really putting so much into their lines. All of this is of course accompanied by gorgeous, painting-like backgrounds that shimmer and glow as Red runs around in them.

I really could ramble about this game so much more, but this review is already sort of long- and besides, this is something you really just have to experience for yourself. If you've ever been a fan of their other games, or are just looking for something new and unique, you should absolutely pick this one up and give it a try.

119267557.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1] 
[b]Transistor[/b] is an action adventure with unique combat mechanics set in a cyberpunk-ish world.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Engaging story with charismatic characters
+ Amazing soundtrack
+ Addictive gameplay
+ Beautiful graphics

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Minor technical issues
- Certain abilities feel too overpowered

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game takes place in a futuristic world, where people can decide the color of the sky and vote for tomorrow’s weather. But one night everything changes, after an unsuccessful assassination attempt on a popular singer, [b]Red[/b], the whole world goes to hell. A woman in question loses her voice, but gains a powerful ally, the titular [b]Transistor[/b], a talking sword that looks like it was cut out of a computer chip. Together they will take revenge on these villains while also saving the world from a mysterious power called [b]The Process[/b]. The story isn’t particularly complicated, but the charismatic companion makes the adventure interesting to follow. The game doesn’t explain everything that happens, but it has lots of subtle details and hidden pieces of info that will provide insight into the world’s inner workings while also leaving a room for interpretation. There aren’t any unpredictable twists, but there are a lot of dramatic moments and the ending is sure to make your eyes wet.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Even if you weren’t caught by the story, you would probably be sucked into this game by its combat mechanics. It features a unique mix of action mechanics and turn based tactics. The game is played like a regular hack and slash, but you have an ability to stop time and plan your actions. After exiting the planning phase, your character will execute those actions almost instantaneously. However, there’s a drawback: this ability has a cooldown and while it’s charging, you can’t use any of your other abilities with a few exceptions, which leaves you vulnerable and makes you think about how you want to approach things. Sometimes it might be better not to use a planning phase at all, and the game actually encourages you by providing an enormous set of abilities to fit your playstyle. There are 16 abilities in total, which you will unlock during the course of game. Each ability can be used in three capacities: as a weapon, as an upgrade, or as a passive ability. I’m not going to count how many possibilities for a character build it gives you, but it’s easy to see that it’s quite a lot. The game also encourages you to experiment with your abilities by unlocking pieces of information after you use an ability in all of its capacities. 

There’s one problem I’ve noticed with this system, that becomes really obvious on a second playthrough. Certain abilities are much stronger than others, which limits your choice of build to a couple of most powerful ones. Although it’s not that big of a deal, since the game allows you to tweak the difficulty with Limiters, they’re unlocked one by one like abilities, but instead of giving you the advantage, they will buff enemies making them stronger, more resilient or enhancing their abilities. And enemies in this game aren’t killed that easily, they spawn white cells after death, that you have to collect, or the enemy will respawn. The enemy variety is great, while 10 enemy types might not seem like much, each of them requires a unique approach and each enemy has a level from 1 to 3. It doesn’t mean their health bar grows with the level, instead they usually gain new abilities, forcing you to switch tactics and surprising you with unexpected challenges that will keep you on your toes most of the time.

[h1]Graphics & Audio[/h1]
The game’s visuals are breathtaking, there are lots of little details in each location. Enemy design is top-notch, you can guess their strengths and weaknesses just by looking at them. The animation looks smooth and watching the protagonist perform her attacks is very satisfying. The voice acting and the music are complementing the visuals nicely. Your helpful companion will never miss an opportunity to comment on the things you see around you, and the music always fits with what’s happening on screen. 

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Specs: AMD Ryzen 9 5900HX, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 Laptop GPU 8GB, 32GB RAM.

At 1080p resolution, the game runs at 60 FPS without any drops. There are, however, some issues with the game. If you use Alt-Tab to change between windows, the game would reset its resolution to the lowest minimum one, and after you reset it, it will run with a noticeable input lag. I’ve also experienced a crash one time when the short cutscene was supposed to start. Thankfully, autosave checkpoints aren’t that far from each other.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Transistor[/b] is an interesting adventure with charismatic characters that you will probably come to miss after finishing the game. And what’s more, the combat mechanics are a great fun, with a vast variety of possible character builds and enemies that require unique approaches. Totally recommended to everyone who knows how to hold a controller.

The story begins with you being attacked by a group of people for reasons you don't understand, your partner saves you but becomes trapped inside the sword (transistor), and you lose your voice, ...and now the world is ending. The gameplay is fun, it's isometric and you don't target enemies to attack them, rather you just face the right direction and use the skill. The story is fairly emotional, and has a happy/sad ending that'll make you want to play again. The NG+ (called recurse in the game) lets you start the story over but with everything you gained before. The soundtrack is fantastic.

There are a few side challenges you can do for some extra exp and limiters you can enable to make the game harder.

I believe my original playthrough was 11 hours, so it's an ideal game to just smash through if you fancy a change from what you normally play.

119061828.review:
Completely different concept that came out perfectly!
The Story follows Red, a singer in the city of Cloudbank and her journey to find the Camerata and put a stop to their on goings while exacting revenge on them trying to assassinate her with the neon sword by the name of the Transistor. The characters in this game are all intriguing with their voice acting coming across as very ominous and mysterious making the player think about their motives. The other way of learning about characters is through gameplay (which i will talk about later in this review) and i think that this works really well in both experimenting with gameplay and advancing the backstory. The story itself can be very basic and easy to follow for those who prefer a less complicated story, however there is enough in here that allows players to explore and learn more about the world and narrative and it makes for a really engaging experience. It manages to take a simple story and tells it in a more impressive way. 
The setting of Cloudbank is just gorgeous with it being this cyberpunk utopia that soon becomes more and more corrupted. I also really like how each area you go to has its own look and the game takes its moments to show off the world that you the player traverse within and allows for their to be commentary on it. 
Visually it looks stunning. Graphically, it ran perfectly with a smooth, constant frame rate and never had a single crash or bug. The Art Direction is truly beautiful and is definitely an improvement on what Bastion had layed down with animations being more smooth and backgrounds having a lot more flow to them. I really love the colour pallet that the game uses as it never shy's away from showing off its neon lights. 
Sound and Audio are also a major improvement and are some of the best parts of the game. The soundtrack is this mix of industrial, drum and bass, beutiful singer songwriter melodies, guitar riffs etc. and with all of this and the inclusion of the beautiful vocals of Ashley Barrett, it really makes for a memorable experience. The sound for things such as the process, transistor abilities and even booting up an OVC terminal all have their own character to them and really adds to the experience. 
In terms of gameplay, I really loved it but i can understand why some people may not. This game takes on a different approach in terms of combat as it goes for a turn based style instead of a hack n slash kind of style that games such as Hades and Bastion are known for. I must say though that the combat system is very fleshed out with there being multiple abilities to mix and match with, giving the player the opportunity to play they want to. There is a wide variety of enemies and offer the player many challenges to overcome. There is a system that pretty much all Supergiant games that i played have that allows the player to make the game harder but offer larger rewards and this game also implements this too which I think is great with there being different challenges and de-buffs that really make the experience that much more intense. The only think i wish this game had was a longer run time because its truly amazing, however there is a new game + mode for those who want more. 
Overall, Transistor was another bold step from Supergiant Games that paid off in the best way possible and had me hook from start to finish.

Despite its incredible visuals and soundtrack, Transistor's style was not met with a level of substance that could keep me playing through it entirely. I believe its shortcomings stem from its incomplete turn-based mechanics and a story that not only loses me in the first 30 minutes but fails to really explain anything worth pursuing for another 6 hours. 

Combat was made janky through its mix of real-time and turn-based combat. Few games are able to fuse both styles well, and its process of plan-execute-survive for a period of time felt very clunky. Your ability to survive depends on if you have the dash feature on hand, if there is sufficient regenerative cover, and if you're able to walk away from your enemy fast enough (there are no sprinting features). You're also unable to use abilities while you are on a cool down before your next execution phase. It eventually got to the point where I thought about what I was really trying to fight for in this game, even though stunning isometric city vistas and other watercolor dreamscapes from their art department did their best to prevent me from thinking that I'm some singer/city planner hybrid that somehow found herself with a giant sword and a vengeance for taking down some quasi-Illuminati group. Total spoilers ahead

In the past, I spurred Transistor for being more complicated, more convoluted, significantly shorter, and perhaps a tad pretentious when compared to Bastion, the title's predecessor. This view stuck with me for many, many years... it's only recently that I've come to appreciate Transistor's unique perspective on pure democracies and tactical semi-turn-based gameplay. Bastion, and more recently Hades, are still more straightforward and superior games, but Transistor has since pulled itself out of my "strictly avoid" category, and I now consider it a proud addition to the Supergiant game collection. 

Transistor is a layer cake of increasingly sophisticated ideas. On the surface it's a game about a seemingly digital utopia being upended by a robotic invasion, with Red (the PC) being the only one who can stop it. Wielding an advanced sword that can absorb the digital souls of fallen citizens (including Red's companion at the start of the game, who travels with you from start to finish), Red must travel through an increasingly deserted & corrupted city, find those responsible for the robotic outbreak, and stop the Process before there's nothing left to save.

However, beyond the surface of Transistor lies a multi-faceted story magnitudes more complex than what initially meets the eye.

It's a story of the issues a pure democracy still contains... something that sci-fi in general tends to overlook, as many stories end with an authoritarian system being overthrown, a democratic one being installed, and everyone expecting every problem to be instantly solved.
It's a story of an artist trying to express themselves in the world, but having to watch as their works inspire radicalism & conflict without meaning to. 
It's a story of love, how a distant companion can only watch their lover struggle from a distance and are seemingly powerless to help. How in the end, one is given enormous power & responsibility, but gives it up in order to be reunited with said lover again.
It's a story how, in a pure democracy where everyone is given a voice, nobody seems to have one. Some who want change/stability feel entirely muted (to paraphrase one of the antagonists: "how could only 4 voices make a difference in a city where everyone has one?"), while others are given unexpected and unprecedented amounts of sway with the crowd, but inadvertently inspire change & radicalism they themselves don't agree with.
It's a story of a city, and indeed culture, constantly changing at the fleeting whims of the people. It's a story about the voiceless taking matters into their own hands, turning to authoritarianism in the attempt to introduce some stability into the system, but end up causing bring destruction upon everyone around them, including themselves.

Transistor can be many things to many people... personally I find it fascinating how an increase of real-world knowledge and broadening of perspective can change one's view of this game. In my youth I considered it convoluted and a bit pretentious, over the years however, I've come to appreciate it's unique plotline and the message it tries to send.

In terms of gameplay, the tactical semi-turn-based style again felt a little complicated/convoluted compared to Bastion's, but it's also something that's come to grow on me as I've advanced in age. There's an enormous amount of different attack styles & synergies to experiment with, some of which cause disgustingly powerful combos and can even merge with themselves in New Game+. Despite not all moves being treated equally, or having perfect synergy with each other, there's enough variety to keep things interesting even on NG+, and the side challenges forcing players to experiment with unique playstyles makes them more appealing & overall help pad out the game's otherwise short runtime.

Overall, Transistor's a game that took many years to grow on me, but now that I've advanced in age & worldview, I've come to appreciate it's more tactical combat system and unique storyline. I won't say that it's perfect, nor argue that Bastion & Hades aren't better/more straight forward games, but I am glad that I gave this one another chance.

Transistor is one of the best games I have ever played. The gameplay, story and presentation all come together to deliver an experience that quite literally left me stunned upon completion. 

The combat in this game is comprised of 'Turns,' where you freeze time and plan out your next series of moves, before executing them and having to dodge all the enemies' attacks while your Turn function recharges. This gives the gameplay a wonderful ebb and flow as you alternate between unloading as much damage as possible on the enemy army, before running for your life as they do the same to you. You also have lots of ways to customise your build, as every attack can be used actively, as one of your 4 main damage dealers, passively, to make your character more powerful, and as an upgrade to one of your active attacks. This provides you with the freedom to experiment with many. many options, most of which are more than powerful enough to succeed in battle. 

As good as Transistor's gameplay is, the aspects most deserving of praise are the game's story, visuals and soundtrack. The city of Cloudbank  is beautiful, and the game's use of lighting, as well as  its layering of 2d effects makes it even better. Darren Korb's soundtrack and Ashley Barrett's vocals add to the lonely atmosphere of the world, and help accentuate the more emotional beats of the story. And what a story it is. I was not emotionally prepared for how this story would make me feel, and I don't think many pieces of media will be able to get a similar reaction out of me. This game made me feel a stronger bond with a silent protagonist and a voice without a body in just 8 hours than most games could do in hundreds. It is not a story I will soon forget.

I didn't particularly care too much for any NPC introduced though, as most of them are just text files you can read. The only thing that was established and remained the same throughout, is Red & the narrator's relationship.

-

[b]/ Combat System[/b]
Bit awkward to put this in neutral when it's the prime gameplay loop. However, it's.. Okay? There's a mechanic that pauses, and you can plan your moves ahead to then swiftly execute them like you're a time-traveller. This mechanic, I like!

What's also nice, is that there's a good amount of abilities to customise your style. These abilities can be used as that- Abilities, but you can also use them as upgrades and as passives. Each ability has a different effect depending on how you use it. This customisation is pretty neat and allows you to tinker with your stuff.

However, and this is where I get neutral about it, is the fact that I either DID like abilities, or didn't. It's about 50/50 for me, in terms of using it or dump it as an upgrade/passive. In my experience, a lot of abilities were short or long range, and just had a different wind-up animation & effects. I didn't feel like the majority of abilities were particularly [i]unique[/i].

Another point is, when you die, you lose access to an ability. You have to restart from the last checkpoint if you lose all your abilities, so you can die like 4 times. Okay, fair penalty. But, here comes the annoying part: If you're a slowpoke like me, and you know, die a lot to Mr. Big Chungus Boss.. You're going to have a fun time using your least favourite basic ability for the rest of the battle. 

Another fun time is finding like 1-3 further checkpoints to ''reset the cooldown'' of your lost ability, so you can use it again. Okay, now I'm temporarily changing up my [i]entire[/i] deck, or at least 1 significant ability. I don't want to be [i]forced[/i] to experiment, you get what I mean?

---

[h1]Negative[/h1]
[b]— The Exploration Feel[/b]
Alright, there's several ways you can go in a level usually. Some will lead to a random room with enemies, and you get a new ability or some shit. Some will just allow you to look at the room and appreciate its art. Some others will make you observe a statue and your sword boyfriend goes googoo gaga. I didn't feel like there was any real incentive to exploring, so I didn't much. Normally, I'm a sucker to look for nooks 'n crannies, but when I can expect one or the other, I can't be bothered. This is also probably the prime reason I finished this game in 3.5 hours, which is [i]way[/i] shorter than I hoped it'd be.

[b]— The Tests[/b]
There are several tests in this game to prove eg. your speed, your stability, you know, be The Best Of The Best. I don't really care for these normally, but to accidentally enter one and then be [i]forced[/i] to do the test, in order to leave? Don't pull that shit on me, man. At least I could kick a beach ball before the test, I guess?

-

[b]— Enemies[/b]
The general few enemies you fight are:
[list]
    [*]Some robot
    [*]A chicken that shits out explosives
    [*]A man that goes invisible sometimes
[*]A dog
[*]A big jerk
[*]Woman
[*] Probably some other little guys that I forgot about
[/list]

While the enemies vary in mechanics, it doesn't feel like it'd be enough to keep someone engaged for hours at a time. Fights are usually over extremely quickly, so in the 'heat' of battle you don't really look up. The only enemies that you have to pay [i]real[/i] attention to are bosses. With these fights, you make [i]real good[/i] use of covering, the planning mechanic, etc. Now, there's a mechanic to make 'fodder fights' more difficult through Limiters, but I didn't see the point of it. Especially if I wasn't enthusiastic enough about combat in the first place.

-

[b]— Price[/b]
I cannot recommend this at full price, especially if you can finish the game as quickly as I did. On sale, sure why not, but I think there are better similar games out there to begin with. [strike]Like [i]Bastion[/i] lol[/strike]

111587645.review:
SuperGiant Games is known for their unique game design approach, their art direction and music. This game has all of these features and I feel is an even better example of what defines them as a studio than Bastion did, and still holds up to modern game standards set by their later titles such as Hades.

Make no mistake, this game is not Hades. Transistor is more about planning, as your playable character is slow and the attacks have a lot of windup and end lag. The game compensates for this in two ways - The Turn() function and the customization system. Customizing your skill loadout in this game is unique in a way that I just haven't seen in other games, before or since Transistor. Each skill stands alone as a usable ability but each one is also designated purpose as a 'sub function' or essentially a skill modifier for all of your other skills. They also can all be equipped in a passive skill slot, further allowing for alterations and customization that lets you design specific combinations or strategies - Singular massive hits, large powerful AOE setups and hit-and-run backstabbing builds are all viable and have lots of room for tweaking and tuning in of themselves.

Turn(), a major feature and necessary function of the game gives you a moment to essentially stop time, breathe and work out a plan. Given a limited meter for any activation of Turn(), you can move and execute skills at the expenditure of this meter to zip around foes and execute skills in succession. The more of this meter you use the longer it will take to cool down and allow you access to your full skillset again so it's sort of a front loaded approach vaguely similar to Braving in Bravely Default but with a firm grip on working within a real time action game such as Transistor. Experts at customizing their loadouts and utilizing their Turn()s will be able to polish off encounters with grace, though the self imposed Limiters the game allows you to turn on add an additional challenge and wrinkles to enemy behaviors in exchange for more rewards for a victory.

From top to bottom the game is meticulously crafted to engage with it's design, keep you gripped on the story and flesh out the world all in just a few hours time. Aiding this is the game's fantastic soundtrack and gorgeous visuals that leans towards an artsy utopia of sorts with a splash of clinical calculation. I'm entirely onboard with the aesthetics of the game. My one major warning is the story length since the game itself isn't exactly a long one, but it does feature a clean progression into a New Game Plus mode that has plenty more to do and see in it with remixed enemy placements and further customization of your skillset for a real test of your planning and wits.

I can't recommend the game enough, and I've bought it so many times on different platforms and for my friends right here on Steam. It's worth your money, every cent.

The only thing that can be done is to "use" them in combat as a skill, which is interesting in concept, but hollow in execution.

A style-over-substance game, with *an* interesting idea (the turn-based combat). Would need a complete restructuring to become a good game with the same combat and artsyle in mind. 109240293.review:
Perhaps like many people, I discovered Supergiant Games through playing Hades. I loved Hades — there were so many things I enjoyed about it. What impressed me the most about it though, was the attention to detail and level of polish the game had, as well as how much love and soul was poured into the game. When playing a game, you can feel almost immediately if it has a soul or not and... well, Hades had a lot of it. This is what got me interested in Supergiant in the first place.

I picked up the rest of their games and decided to play them all. Transistor was next on my list. I didn't think it would be possible but I actually enjoyed Transistor even more than Hades. You can see the early influences of Hades in this game — most obviously in the isometric view but also in the combat moves (called functions in Transistor) as well as the enemies' combat moves.

Whereas the ending of Hades feels somewhat open-ended, Transistor plays like a fully closed loop. In the case of this game, the scope of the game feels just right — not too ambitious nor lacking. What the devs wanted to achieve was perfect for the ultimate capability of the game itself. It's always very pleasing when this happens (rather than the writing team, etc. biting off more than they can chew).

The lore of this game is abstract, yet it is very easy to empathize with the characters. I am grateful to Supergiant for not attempting to explain every detail of the lore here, unlike in some franchises where the plot has gotten extremely convoluted to the point of nonsensical. The story in Transistor is perfectly intriguing. The characters are relatable. The predicament is understandable and does not contradict itself. The gameplay requires patience but is never boring. The combat is so unique and innovative.

This is a near perfect game. Having studied math and computer science in college, I loved all the mathematical allusions placed throughout the game. There are very few creative works which attempt to marry computational science with fiction, and do so in a believable way — most sci-fi requires extreme suspension of belief but the science in this game is sound. I really can't think of anything in this game I didn't like. Controlling Red felt clunky at times, but even that was justified since she's lugging around a huge sword the whole game.

The choice to make the protagonist female just elevates this game to legendary status in my eyes. I haven't tried the recursion yet, since I just binged the main storyline. I have little doubt that new game+ will be awesome though, along with the other two Supergiant games I have left to play.

There's even more I'd like to say but maybe next time. TL;DR — you have to play this game.

108892084.review:
[b]An animated painting designed by Gustav Klimt himself.[/b]

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]RATING:[/th]
        [th]🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟 5/5[/th]
[th]PERFECT GAME[/th]
    [/tr]
[/table]


[h1]Context[/h1]
To be honest I am one of the few people who did not liked Bastion, I found it boring and I have spent less than 3 hours playing it. I have it in my library and I might give it another try sooner or later. However, Transistor was quite the opposite, it caught me from the first musical notes when I pressed the play button, and the voice acting, visuals and gameplay kept me playing non-stop for over 5 hours. I have completed it 3 times in 4 days, last run took me only ~one hour to complete.


[h1]Atmosphere, Visuals and Music[/h1]
Visually speaking it is the type of game that you could make a beautiful wallpaper with every single screenshot you take.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2708849079

 It was clearly inspired by the works of art of Gustav Klimt and other Art nouveau artists, the obsession with gold leaf and divinized elegant womens is unmistakable.

Giantgames managed to combine it with a (definetly not a Cyberpunk) brand new aesthetic to develope a genuine world that is closer to a painting than it is to a video game. Can we come to a consensus and call it CyberTransistor aesthetic? No? Ok.

I didn't quite liked the music in general, but it fits the game in the good way and I loved the two main themes, which are perfect.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ql8K3KJyWgY


[h1]Plot overview (spoilers free)[/h1]
I can't speak too much about it without giving some spoilers, since the plot is really simple on the surface and can be explained in two lines. However, I can say that it is a beautiful yet tragic love story between a singer that lost her voice and a boxer's voice that has lost his body in a world where everything that the majority votes for becomes the "reality" of that day.

You could try to find the real meaning hiding behind this game for hours, which is what I most liked about it, so I won't ruin it for you.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
I expected it to be a classic hack 'n slash game, which is ok,  but thanks to its "Turn" system where the next moves can be planned and with a considerable cooldown before you can use it again, it achieves a dynamism that makes it probably the most unique game of its kind.

The objective is simple, defeat the so-called "Process" which are the enemies.

You have 16 skills called "Functions" that you can combine however you want to create tons of different effects to suit your playstyle. Equipping the functions requires MEM, which is the equivalent of capacity.

There are also 10 debuffs that you can apply to strengthen the enemies while you gain more experience by defeating them, these are called "Limiters".

Here you can see some of my favorite combinations that carried me through new game+. They worked even with all 10 Limiters activated at the same time. (You will have to remove a few to have enough MEM if you turn on the Limiter that drains MEM.)

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2708836585


[h1]World and Exploration[/h1]
Cloudbank is a linear city that has no collectibles or anything that can distract you from your main mission. It is a world that feels close to a Communist Matrix/Tron world, since the reality is designed by the votes of the people thanks to the Transistor as I mentioned.

The only thing that can distract you is a door that appears in certain places called "Back Door", which is a sandbox with, well... sand, literally. It is a beach where you can practice combos and overcome challenges to unlock new soundtracks and some achievements.


[h1]Misc[/h1]
[list]

[*]The game can last approximately 8 hours in your first run.

[*]It has replayability potential.

[*]Achievements are fun and easy to accomplish.

[*]It has New Game++.

[*]You can use "Humming and Flourish" by holding down the LB and RB button respectively on your controller.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]The lack of some quality of life characteristics to quick equip your builds or even save them.

[*]Enemies in the Back Door Sandbox practice can't harm you, so you can't test healing Functions.

[*]The Limiters doesn't complicate the combat at all, what they do is mess up your quality of life, which is not worth it for only an extra 32% of experience that has no real use when you get to Max Rank anyway.

[*]Whenever your health bar is depleted you lose one of your Functions instead of dying, forcing you to play without that specific skill for some time, thankfully you can get back to your last save.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Transistor is a game that requires testing dozens of different builds and investigating the effects of each one, if you like to experiment and try new things up, this game is for you.

It is a beautiful minimalistic short game with an unforgetable immersion and an emotive love story that might give you goosebumps and even make you cry at some points if you are immersed enough into the story.

I had plenty of fun playing it multiple times and each time I was astonished by its visuals, gameplay and story, it is a game that has everything you will ever ask from a perfect game.

It may seem short, but each frame is like watching a different painting.


[h1]To buy or not to buy?[/h1]
Yes, Highly recommendable. Too short for a full price, but a must buy during a Sale.


See you in the Country.

107225348.review:
A small work of art, truly sets the mark for storytelling.

As with all other Supergiant games so far, the presentation carries the game. The game is set in a beautiful pastel, hand drawn, [i]art nouveau[/i] inspired utopian megacity. While the city is empty of other people, the little details scattered around the world succeed in telling the story of how things were and how they are going to be due to the events of the game.
The stellar music contributes to the storytelling. The tone and lyrics contributes to narrating the story of the characters you meet and the feelings of the protagonist towards the world and the events. A second, focused listening is suggested to fully appreciate the carefully crafted narrative without the threat of enemies on the screen.

The gameplay is a bit more involved compared to Bastion, with two main new elements. 
First, attacks can be improved with multiple modifiers (instead of the couple alternative routes present in Bastion) chosen by the user and unlocked through the entire game. Straight skillshots, debuffs, modifiers, status effects can all be mixed and combined in many different variations. The loadout can only be changed between battles at specific points (frequent enough to not be a problem) without having to respec the entire progression.
Second, the real time isometric brawl can be transformed in a sort of turn based combat. Time can be frozen to plan several moves ahead, creating an alternating pattern of rushing enemies down and avoiding counterattacks while waiting for the next turn to attack. Again, the system is very free flow, and pretty much never boxes you in a single playstyle.

I don't want to talk about the story too much because the way the game builds the world through decrypting character logs and interacting with the environment is fascinating and a very important part of the experience. I feel it left me with as many answers as questions, which may or may not be your cup of tea.

Just long enough to not overstay its welcome, with a NG+ mode with tougher enemies and more skill combos, and a set of optional challenges. Highly recommended.
