   In a 'nutshell' here's a bit of the story:
   Cloudbank is a virtual utopia. Citizens democratically vote on everything, from the next big building project to what the weather is going to be. When the polls end, administrators execute the changes from behind the curtain.
   Choice reigns in Cloudbank. Large changes occur daily. And "when everything changes, nothing changes." That's the motto of the Camarata. They're interesting because they see Cloudbank as a dystopia.
   Grant was an administrator. He executed changes voted by the majority. He also had to ignore his own opinions and feelings on the changes. This drained him to a point where he could no longer go forward.
   Asher was frustrated with Cloudbank's shoddy historical records. When change is instant, and everyone lives in the present, historical records become impossible to maintain.
   Royce was irked by the fact that everything could be changed on the whim of the majority. None of his designs were allowed to have any permanence, regardless of how much effort he put in them.
   Grant, Asher, and Royce no longer wanted change to be a majority vote. They wanted change to happen when it was needed, not wanted. By using his supernerd math skills, Royce found his way to the Process, the entity/source-code used to shape and re-shape Cloudbank. As Royce further empowered the Process, he also worked on a way to control it - the Transistor (hey, that's the name of the game!)
  The Transistor is the key to controlling the Process, therefore the key to low-key being God, at least in the virtual world Cloudbank is part of. And in order to be the best possible key, the Camarata decided that the Transistor required several Functions. Functions are obtained by... letting talented people be partially Processed... and then killing or absorbing them with the Transistor.
   Cue Sybil, the last person to join the Camarata. As the social scout, she finds and approaches said talented people. And the Camarata abducts them...  And then kills them... And forever imprisons a part of their sentience... for the greater good of Cloudbank.
   Red, the protagonist, is a talented singer. The Camarata want her Function. What ever could go wrong?

   ...this is just the prelude of the game. Yeah, the story and writing are actually awesome! Going through the game also serves as some rich food for thought for anyone with a bit of a philosophy itch. 
   And it's not just the story that's awesome. In terms of visuals, the character design, Cloudbank's many stages, the cinematics, the UI, the HUD, the particles - awesome. In terms of audio, the voice acting, the music, the sounds - awesome. The variety of skill customization, and the way the user gets to set their own difficulty level - awesome.
  [i]Supergiant[/i] put in a lot of attention to detail in order give us both a game and a one-of-a-kind work of art. While [i]Transistor[/i] is [i]Bastion's[/i] successor, it is not a sequel. It shows the growth that the devs at [i]Supergiant[/i] went through.

   Lemme just quickly touch up on what I didn't enjoy that much - the combat. As soon as I unlocked a limiter I enabled it, and I do not recommend this. I did it for the XP boost and while level-ups always felt nice, the many fights did not. I went through the whole game and the recursion without finding a build I was perfectly comfortable with. Having Turn() off cooldown and being forced to run around is not fun. Spending 3 MEM to upgrade a Function with Jaunt() or to just equip it as an active or a passive also is not fun.
   I found that Purge() upgraded with Crash() and Breach() let me spam a lot homing, long-range, stun-locking DoTs. However, it dealt almost no damage and the stun doesn't work on bosses and masked enemies.
   I liked Void() upgraded with Bounce() and Get() but swapping out Bounce() for Crash() had better results overall. This is a great CC and debuff but it deals zero damage so I threw in a Load() passive whenever I could and just kept spamming until a packet spawned.
   I tried out Cull() upgraded with Load() and Void() for good damage but found Tap() upgraded with Breach() and Void() to be more reliable overall.
   Get() was a must-have as a passive for me though.
   As I gained more Limiters and enemies got harder I found it harder and harder to use Turn(), so I stopped using it. Jaunt () and Ping () became a lot less important after that.
   I found the boss fights to be more than just challenging in the Recursion with all 10 Limiters on. I'd advise against that.

  [i]Transistor[/i] came out in 2014 and it neither looks nor feels its age. It doesn't suffer from outdated graphics or narrative or a done-to-death gimmick. It doesn't rely on community mods or a community patch for the best experience. It features minimal RNG and no grinding. It doesn't have expansions, DLCs, loot boxes, or micro-transactions. Even the achievements feel right...
   Yeah, recommended. 5/5 cells, would review again!

If there's one thing that simply must be said about Transistor it's that the game is absolutely -gorgeous-.

The central mechanic of being able to stop time and pre-plan your moves also gives several avenues of play - are you the type to slow down the battle and plan your best move through this, play in real-time (as if a proto-version of Supergiant's next game, hades), or a mix of both?
While it isn't exactly the hardest or most complex combat ever envisioned, it's still a lot of fun to try out various options and see what kind of builds you can make.

Transistor is a cyberpunk tale of romance, with a hybrid turn-based/real-time RPG combat system. Tl;dr: story and soundtrack are on par with Bastion, even if the gameplay itself is not.

There are quite a few downsides to this game. It has limiters similar to Bastion's idols, which can be toggled on for extra challenge/XP at checkpoints, but they start to feel cheap at times (one of these limiters wrecks any functions you uninstall and renders them unuseable until the next checkpoint you configure your sword at, and another limiter causes enemies to drop cells on death that inflict damage onto you upon absorption, and it's hard to quickly tell the difference in the heat of the moment). It has a Turn function to let you freeze combat and queue up actions/functions with the threat of enemy bombardment minimised, which can also let you outrun enemies to get away or line up shots to hit them before they can evade, but the downside is that you're locked out of using any functions until your Turn() function has recharged, and enemies can move while you perform your attacks, meaning you might waste a Turn aiming and empty space because a Fetch moved an inch to the right. During combat your fight area is usually tiny as well with a border you can't escape, so you can't run far enough to be safe from enemies using the remainder of your Turn cooldown chasing you into a corner and shooting at you. Losing a full bar of health causes your sword to consume one of your (up to 4) active functions to refill your health, making the fight and subsequent game harder, as you can expect fights to get progressively challenging. I gave up on the game for a week when I got to the final boss fight, after facing several groups of cloaked enemies that remained invulnerable for 99% of the time, only showing an opportunity to strike for half a second at a time.

I started to have fun with the game right at the end of my first playthrough, when I discovered effective builds to beat the final boss and generally survive Recursion (NG+) without having to call on Turn(), which as it turns out, becomes a crutch that slows you down if you keep relying on it beyond your first playthrough. The game's Steam Community Guides really saved me many headaches there. Not being distracted by the awfully-thought-out combat system meant that for my second playthrough, I could experience the story and music the way the developers intended, and I began to enjoy every minute of it.

As for the story itself, it's similar to Bastion. Person in dead/dying world, first order of business is trying to survive, and somewhere along the way, they [spoiler]find the power to shape their reality[/spoiler]. No point in sharing fan theories about the nature of the Process and Cloudbank here, but it's a fun read. It has a more mysterious, intriguing, and subtle atmosphere compared to Bastion which does help.

Bottom line, I think it's pretty fun IF you can manage to get past the very experimental-feeling combat system.

Going into this I remember the game left me feeling cold on my first playthrough, now having replayed I can better identify why. Transistor plays like  a realtime w/pause tactics game. You get fucked pretty quickly if you don't use the queuing system well. It runs on a stamina meter of sorts that's drained based on your inputs. The game does a great job of letting you customize your moveset. It's very malleable, reminding me of the flexibility of the brawler Godhand. You can take a basic melee attack, and stack different modifiers, like damage over time, or an AOE effect that chains its damage to nearby foes. I do feel like the game is a bit on the easy side, such that once you find a favorite tactic, you can pretty much spam it for the rest of the game. Stacking on difficulty modifiers helps tremendously with this and encourages you to experiment with your inputs, as "dying" here means losing temporary access to a specific module. I had a much better time with the combat as I kept stacking these modifiers against myself and continually engaging with the new modifiers to find what worked best for my playstyle. In sum, if you don't care for the game's story whatsoever and are just interested in the combat, I think the game succeeds in providing a deep enough toolset to find new ways to change your play. I do wish the game's enemies not only had more personality, but had more moves that encouraged you to change your tactics. Considering you can equip a generous amount of inputs at one time, the enemies don't have enough moves themselves to force you to change your tactics all that much.  

Speaking of story, I really disliked that much of it is relegated to menu screens that unlock piecemeal as you change up your inputs. You never engage with a majority of the cast, so it was hard for me to give a fuck about any of it. At the very least, the connection between you (Red) and the Sword is well done. I thought it was a neat detail to have Red communicate with the Sword via the News Terminals, but I do wish there was more player choice there. 

The game's aesthetics are strong. The artwork is easy on the eyes, the enemies are easy to read, and the game some cool "travel" cutscenes as well. I enjoyed the inclusion of the "safe room" where you can attempt unique combat exercises using specific inputs. In sum, I wish the combat was deeper, as all you really need to do is kite to win. I wish there were more enemies that could entrap you, or restrict the playspace. That said, I appreciate the unique combat experience. A bit of a shame that the storytelling fell completely flat for me, but at the very least the game's aesthetics, music, and core combat experience are a joy to experience, especially when they are all working together.

This game was a very good experience.
The combat formula, mixing real time with a time stopping ability limited by a resource  is ingenious. I thought it might be boring, but I never tired of planning the actions and watching everything develop in accelerated frame rate, as in an action movie! Also, had some high adrenaline moments where enemies attacks were getting very close and I  needed a few more seconds to activate the turn planning and get out of a stick situation. Nonetheless, the game is quite forgiving on combat, as it takes a lot for your to actually fall, but you lose your attacks as you take more and more damage. This way it might be easier to brute force some combats (but not all), but, when you grasp the system and create some good combinations, it is a joy to plan combat and see how a seemingly hard enemy can be taken down easily. 
One feature that might annoy players is that leveling up have you choosing your rewards, which means that, sometimes, you have to choose between two good abilities, or upgrading different capacities, both of which are very good. Anything not chosen at a time will be available on later levels, but it is unlikely to get them all in a single play through.

The art of the game is gorgeous: visual style, music and voice work, all top notch. 
The world build was also very inspired. If you like some science fiction, there is a lot to enjoy there. Even unlocking all the profile info for the characters whose your powers is based on was a joy, as they were well written and intriguing. 
The plot of the game is very good, but there is not a lot of hand holding. I mean, if you don follow closely, it might not make that much sense, with some events and motivations being implied and not stated. This is good writing for me, as the reader use his own thoughts to make sense of what happened. Having followed the stories of the people associated with each of your abilities also helps to paint the complete picture. 
Although the game was great, there low point for me are the enemies. The bosses were good, but there were a few of them. The regular enemies are nice, but there are little variation. Again, this is a small point on the overall quality of the game, it is not even bad, just not as memorable as the other highlights I had.
Also, the game is rather short, at least compared with time I spent on other Supergiant games. Nonetheless, given the mechanics and the story, I think it has a good duration, and more than this would risk adding boring times. There is an option of a new game plus, that might be good for people wanting more of the combat, challenge and/or hunt for achievements. I have not tried it, but might come back to this challenge mainly for experimenting the abilities I had not used and maybe try some additional limiters. Also, as the enemies are stronger, there could be some new ones, who knows?

Finally, there are a ton of references to computing, specially for people used to terminal commands and networking, which I appreciated.
Overall, a great game, keeping on par with the high standards of quality and innovation I came to expect from Supergiant.

99694957.review:
"Hey Red. We're not going to get away with this are we?"

[i]Transistor[/i] is a science fiction action role-playing video game developed and published by Supergiant Games.

[b]Story[/b]
Set in futuristic Cloudbank you play as Red, a famous singer. Due to a series of unfortunate events, she ends up being attacked by The Process, robotic force controlled by a organization called Camerata, and ends up losing her voice. During the escape she aquires Transistor, a powerful and mysterious greatsword-like weapon which she uses to fight back and retrieve what has been taken from her, while learning more about events that occured, and her new powerful ally.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Similar to first Supergiants Games game [i]Bastion[/i], Transistor is played from an isometric point of view and is a linear title, with main difference being lack of option to replay areas you have already completed. Travel through a series of locations while battling The Process and improving along the way.

Main part of the gameplay, combat, features Red and Transistor teaming up to take on their enemies using abilities called Functions. Those come in different shapes and sizes but being pain in the neck of the Process is their shared goal.
Majority of them is nothing unusual, with melee, ranged, or area of effect attacks being mixed with options such as setting up traps or turning enemies into allies.

Game contains both real-time combat where you can take Process head on, but after few areas you will realize it's not the best way to fight as you are outnumbered and overwhelmed, and a main focus of it, a turn based twist as Red can use Transistor to enter frozen planning mode called Turn(). In this mode time slows, Red hums, and your get to plan out your moves. Here you can create function combinations to deal massive damage or move away from danger and find a safe spot, depending on your current needs. Each action in Turn, from movement to function use costs action points, which will refill after you are done using said mode. While your points refill, you are defenseless so all you can do is find a cover and hope those few seconds can quickly pass. Game does contain an option of dodging, but it is a "Not that good and needs to be unlocked first" function.
If enemies hit you, you recive damage. Recive more than you can take and...continue to fight? When you lose a healthbar, instead of usual Game Over screen, game blocks you from using one of the functions you had in your loadout and restores your health. However if you will lose access to all functions you currently use, that will be the end, obviously.

After done fight you reap the rewards, here them being experience points. Gathering enough xp levels you up, allowing you to unlock a new function, additional slot in Transistor, or a limiter.
Limiters are similar to Idols from Bastion. They make your life tougher, but using them gives you XP bonus, allowing you to level up faster.
Worth mentioning that as you level up and progress in the game, Process also improves, whether by adding new types of enemies, or pulling out better versions of previous ones with new abilities.

Outside of combat you can find Access Points which serve as checkpoints and allow you to customize your loadout. Here you can go wild with all functions and slots you have unlocked, enable/disable limiters, or learn more about different characters from Cloudbank, if you will unlock such information.

While you can use functions however you desire - by putting them as primary abilities you will use in combat, secondaries that can improve functions in primary slots, allowing you to upgrade powerful functions even further, or as passive bonuses - limitation comes in form of MEM. Every function uses specific amount of Memory, and you have a limited amount of it available. So besides having to think about which function you want in different slots, you have to look at the MEM count. Amount of MEM you can use can be increased, as a reward for leveling up.

Besides access points, while exploring you can interract with few enviroment elements including terminals, stop by and listen to Red humming, or occasionally find doors to a peaceful location where you can train or challenge yourself in tests for xp and unlockable music tracks available to listen in-game!

[b]Playtime, replayability and other modes[/b]
It took me 7 hours to beat Transistor, that is with spending time on function mixing and completing all tests possible during first playthrough, so you can drop that time to 6, even 5 hours if you will haste.

Good news lies in Recursion Mode, which is a New Game+ where you keep your progress, while game from the start features every enemy you encountered before, plus unlocks further tests that were unavailable previously, adding a necessary replayability aspect to the game.

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
Strongest elements of Transistor are audiovisual design and combat.

Soundtrack composed by Darren Korb and featuring lovely voice of Ashley Barrett is not only outstanding, adding personality and life to the game, but lyrical songs add a piece of storytelling as those are "composed" by Red, expressing her thoughts and memories through it as she can't do it herself in the game. 
One of my personal favourites when it comes to soundtracks in video games. 

Charming soundtrack goes well with beautiful Cloudbank as walking through this futuristic city is a pleasure of it's own, and also is a factor in understanding the story and events that happen in the game.
And when you can't enjoy the city due to Process, you can appreciate beating them!
Sheer amount of different combinations you can make from fight to fight will allow everyone to find preferable playstyle, and thanks to good progression system it's never overwhelming you. Game constantly wants you to experiment with functions and rewards it with more lore about the game, never putting too much pressure on a player during combat yet not going easy on you, making fights a fair challenge, with limiters adding difficulty for those who want it, plus constant addition and improvement of encountered enemies constantly force you to adapt. 

While far from being bad, storytelling is one of the more "mixed" points of Transistor, especially for those who might attempt to "rush" through the game. Tied to worldbuilding which some might miss out on, bittersweat ending that won't satisfy everyone and quite often game due to narrative leaves more questions than answers in specific topics. Personally I found it good enough, however I understand why some players will not enjoy it, as I found flaws in my second, slightly rushed playthrough.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
Due to me being late as always and playing 2014 game..a bit later, quality of Supergiant Games titles is already known at this point, especially after Hades, which I also had the pleasure of recently dipping into it for more than few hours that I cloaked at the release, resulting in Supergiant Games really going up on my virtual, would-make-it-if-not-lazy list of favourite developers, proving how quality beats quantity and I cannot wait to get my hands on Pyre. 

Transistor proves that Bastion was no one-hit wonder. With wonderful audiovisual design, flexible combat and great progression system, this outstanding title can only be highly recommended!

99173768.review:
Transistor is a top down isometric, skill gated, real time combat, button mashing, noir RPG. It is also a side scrolling, checkpointed, tactical combat, cyberpunk action-adventure. Yes, you read that right.

An interesting but short story, the game feels a lot like a convention demo, it drops you almost directly into the action and worries about story telling later. You play as Red, a singer with a stolen voice that has, for reasons that are never quite explained, managed to acquire a weapon of extreme power that seems to have sucked out the soul of a guy that appears to have been stalking her. She then goes on a robot murder spree to end a threat that’s never properly introduced for reasons we’ll probably never know. 

But anyway, onward!

Pros:
The game is beautiful, very well scored, and atmospheric. The music and art somehow blend the 20’s noir and cyberpunk elements incredibly well.
The game has a lot of choice in terms of skill lay out, meaning a large number of play styles are catered for, it’s just a matter of exploring and finding your own flavour of play.
The world building and little extras really give the game a nice well thought out feel. The ‘back doors’ provide a nice rest and some additional challenges, the little alcoves with extra information, the ability to see how others have played. These little isolated mechanics tie together nicely to help give the game a much needed feeling of depth.

Cons:
The skills are gated by level, and while there is a huge variety, once you find your First Order Optimal Strategy a huge chunk of the game is lost. It simply becomes a puzzle to see how much of the lore you can mine from the different slots they can occupy while maintaining efficiency.
The story is paper thin, as are the characters. There is a huge volume of room to manoeuvre though, if what is laid down as bones were fleshed out.  Thing is, this really does make the game forgettable at best and not really replayable, though the NG+ mode adds a splash of challenge in. 
The game grows quite stale by the end. The above two con’s add up to quite a repetitive and predictable experience. Everything you do and learn in the first 10 minutes underpins the entire 8 hour experience.

Suggested improvements:
The game is full of good ideas, tight mechanics, and has a fun core gameplay loop. Keeping this fresh with limitations throughout, and not just in the challenge sections, could really help the game feel fresh the whole way through.
The game doesn’t really have any challenge. At the time of writing I’d just had my fill, about an hour and a half into the NG+ mode. Some better control over the limiters, perhaps with sliding values could have injected some excitement. 

Overall recommendation:
This game will take about 2-3 evenings to complete if you work full time. It’s fun enough and short enough that it doesn’t grow too old too quickly. It’s pretty accessible and extremely forgiving, with combinations of skills that can make it even more so.
That said, I don’t think it’s worth the 15 quid asking price. If you see it in a bundle with other stuff you want? It’ll add value for sure. If it goes on sale for less than 10 quid? It’s worth it.

TL;DR - The game is thoroughly polished and highly immersive.  It's like opening a book which guides you along the path of a cyberpunk Armageddon.

The combat style is fantastic.  It is a format which challenges and rewards reflexes, pre-planning strategies, tactics, and experimentation.  It encourages you both [b]to slow down[/b] and [b]to act on instinct[/b], striking a healthy balance between agency and urgency.  It is this game's #1 draw to replayability.

The visual style is absolutely gorgeous.  It is so polished and thematically sound that it will slip under the radar until you stop to appreciate it.  Then, it blows up your senses with a feeling that this world has been building and evolving for years before your visit.  From the general UI, to the combat UI, to the environment, to the combat interface, to the particle effects:  the whole experience is an expertly polished treat.

Nearly every sound feels [spoiler]BARK![/spoiler] properly engineered and appropriate. [spoiler]I found it especially pleasing to open OVC terminals... such a rich and deep fanfare.[/spoiler]  The FX processing and dynamic musical elements are top-shelf.  While most battles do not pose a problem, insanely large battles, however, do seem to lack high-quantity-channel support.  It may be due to cross-compatibility issues or a lack of forward thinking, but this instance of channel-dropping is rare.

The star of the show, however, is the soundtrack.  It is, without a doubt, the thread which holds together the theme and feel of this game.  Darren Korb and Ashley Barrett (along with the programmers who [i]dynamically integrate the music[/i]) change what could have been only an "adequate" sensory experience into an [i]engaging journey[/i].  Listening to the soundtrack alone will not surpass the experience of the game and playing the game alone will not surpass the soundtrack.  I <3 this so much.

The story seems to fall short on some people, but there's enough in there to keep driving the narrative forward.  I wouldn't call this the strongest point of the game as it still seems to leave some questions unanswered and motivations unexplored.  I will say that the premise is intriguing and capably integrated into the experience enough to not totally fall apart on itself.  There's a fair bit of in-game reading involved for some of the backstory, as well as audio logs, but overall, the experience is well paced.

The achievements are not particularly in-depth, but there is a good logical progression to them.  I found myself actually achievement hunting (to 100%!--unusual for me) with this game because it was an excuse to continue enjoying the combat.  They offered a moderate challenge, as well.

Not every game is going to sate every craving, so, here are some things I'd have like to have seen:
-An "endless" mode where you could take on droves of ever-increasing-numbers of enemies in larger, more complex battlefields.  [spoiler]The in-game limiters are somewhat challenging, however, as some situations may result in a "nearly infinite" battle might take place.  Proceed with caution[/spoiler]
-Longer story.  I wanted to see more of the city and meet more occupants.  It could have drawn out the combat, fleshed out some of the character motivations, and made it feel a little more like an RPG.
-A little greater variety of enemies... maybe with some interactive or environmental dangers (like traps).

I definitely recommend this game.  I've played through it twice and while editing this review, a third time.  Now, it's your Turn().

Edit:  3 playthroughs now.  I just can't stay away.  This combat is too damn good.

98367754.review:
Transistor is, for me at least, somehow less than the sum of its parts. An accomplished isometric brawler with a fun slo-mo tactical twist, the beautiful visuals and scintillating music you’d expect from a Supergiant Games production, and an intriguing plot, Transistor contains all the ingredients for success. And yet. The difficult second album following Supergiant’s lauded debut Bastion, Transistor perhaps tries to do too much, and succeeds only diffusely, never quite bringing it all together into a successful whole.

MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD. You are Red, a famous singer, living in the post-scarcity utopia of Cloudbank. Your lover is now a sword (and it may be here that things become slightly difficult to follow), which has also stolen your voice, and the city is being absorbed and / or overrun by the Process, a sinister AI unleashed by the Camerata. The Camerata, you see, want… something? Probably power. Let’s say they want power. And they hate Red, because… she… Well, anyway, the Process definitely is out of control, and its ultimate aim is… to turn everything into white cubes… because…

Look, you may call me a dolt for failing to understand what on earth is going on in Transistor. It’s a plot-heavy campaign, with plenty of Logan Cunningham’s top-notch whiskey-and-leather voiceover work as well as lengthy cutscenes and reams of text. But what it all adds up to, I couldn’t tell you. Cloudbank is a novel setting for a video game, an upliftingly utopian science fiction reminiscent of Alistair Reynolds’ Blue Remembered Earth, sadly under-utilised and quickly overrun by a fairly generic evil horde. Red’s vocals are beautifully worked into the haunting soundtrack, and any game with a button that lets you hum along deserves at least three bonus points. But the wonderful individual artistic contributions are ultimately let down by Transistor’s script, which feels both loose and verbose. Difficulties in establishing who Red is, what her relationship is to her talking sword mate (never named), and what either of them want, gives the first half of the game in particular the irritatingly abstract feel of a creative writing student’s mid-term project. Development limitations, I imagine, cut Red off from ever actually meeting any of the game’s sizeable cast, who have always just died, or just escaped, prior to her arrival. You only ever interact with the Process. It leaves the world feeling empty and unreal. SPOILERS END.

Combat, at least, is fun, and workable with a keyboard and mouse. Your talking sword mate comes in handy for battering the Process, as well as firing off energy-bullets and lightning and whatnot. Better still, if things are getting hairy, you can enter slo-mo Transistor Time, called TURN() for reasons known only to the developers, which allows you to set up and execute a highly-satisfying series of attacks and manoeuvers. As you progress you’ll acquire and set up powers, modifiers and buffs with names like JAUNT() and PING () and MASK (), using the weird premise of integrating dead personalities into your sword’s suite of abilities. It’s a highly customable, somewhat fiddly system that’s perhaps a little too freeform, capable of concocting both broken and overpowered builds. But it does lead to plenty of variety in the game’s many combat encounters, and lets you feel smart when you successfully design a custom build to overcome one of Transistor’s fun optional challenge missions.

Overall, Transistor offers satisfying combat, gorgeous visuals and music, and an incomprehensible plot. How much the latter affects your enjoyment will be a matter of personal taste. I’d cautiously recommend this game to an interested player, but would happily suggest both its predecessor Bastion and successor Hades to be superior showcases for Supergiant’s unquestionable talent.

Highly recommend! 24.7 hours to obtain 100% Achievements. This is a unique game... Is it turn-based? It can be. Your choice. Does it have increasing difficulty? Again, that is your choice. This game is different in that for a game that isn't terribly long by itself, it truly is what you make of it with a combination of unusual game mechanics.

The game is based around a weapon called the Transistor that can stop time and absorb Functions left from things called traces. This transistor also is sentient and is the narrator for the game as you find out that your voice has been taken from you. As you level up, you can combine different Functions in one of three ways - base, upgrade or passive. Each time you use a Function in a different way, you learn more about the entity that spawned its trace (additional world lore). The same is true that you can unlock Limiters that will help you level up quicker at the cost of debuffs in each encounter. The balance between Limiters and Functions is what makes this game really interesting.

Sure you can play real time but your actions are slow and clunky. You can freeze time which will allow you to move quick and attack without issue... But the Process evolves. You will face enemies that can't take damage as they are masked. You are pushed out of your time stop because some enemies create disruption areas that knock you out of your Turn that you couldn't see because other enemies blinded you with a fog of war. There is a lot to this game but you learn quickly or else.

Pros:
- Visually stunning and I purchased the soundtrack since it was worth every penny
- Combination of Functions makes gameplay a unique style all your own with all the various combinations
- Limiters increase the difficulty or challenge rating to a level of your choosing
- Story is amazing and voice actors were great choices even though the game didn't really use facial animations
- Trials in the hideout were enjoyable fairly difficult which made for a great test of skills
- Replayability was a requirement for achievement hunting and to unlock new trials in the hangout area
Cons:
- Final boss was weak unfortunately... It would've been better to have some minions each time you knocked him out
- Nothing really new was introduced on replays... Slightly more difficult but only SLIGHTLY

97929281.review:
Seven years and two games later, Transistor still stands tall as one of Supergiant's greats and a masterclass in storytelling. Dazzlingly good art, top-notch voice acting and thoughtful audio design come together to paint a living world. 

The action combat isn't the game's strongest aspect - yet, it's nothing to scoff at either. Transistor's movement and combat actions have aged well, feeling just as crisp now as they did over half a decade ago. The ability to pause, enter Turn() and plan your future actions is a solid twist on an otherwise fairly standard top down action game, creating interesting strategic opportunities for the player.

I cannot emphasize enough how much attention to detail was paid in the development of this game. In contrast to its digitized city setting, the game's story is told organically through its world through one-liner descriptions of the objects in the level, interactive terminals that poll passers-by on random topics, and the Transistor's ever-present narration of the events unfolding. While the narrative itself wasn't the most compelling for me, I absolutely loved how the game tried to communicate it to me through all these little details.

Transistor still holds its own among the other isometric/top down action games released in the past two years, despite being seven years old. I'd recommend this to anyone who's tried Hades and is looking for another mesmerizing experience crafted by Supergiant Games.

Overall, Transistor is a good game. The music ranges from catchy to deeply melancholic depending on the needs of the narrative and melding of real-time and turn-based combat from an isometric perspective is incredibly well done allowing for a lot of different strategies and truly compelling the player to experiment. However, Transistor is also example of the difference between writing lore and writing a story. The lore of Transistor is well-made. The city of Cloudbank, the villainous Camerata and all of the processed people whose stories you gradually uncover through using abilities are really cool. However, the story itself is not nearly as strong as the foundation it is built on. Red gets rare opportunities to communicate through the terminals, but is otherwise mostly given a personality through what other people think of her. Arguably, her actions speak to her personality, she is given the option to flee Cloudbank but doesn't, for example. But these moments are rare. The transistor itself, or the man Red can hear, does get a strong personality. He is protective over Red, somewhat conflict averse and somewhat restrained in his ability to showcase emotion (except when in his equivalent of being drunk). The issue for me is that the transistor mostly just responds to the environment and Red cannot speak. It gives opportunity for the player to really connect to these characters. And, most damningly, it makes the ending feel unearned. I will not spoil it here, but the ending left a rather sour taste in my mouth, it made Red even less of a person from my point of view. 

To make a very long review shorter, Transistor is a great game with impressive visuals and strong sound design that could have used a bit more development in the story department to make it a true classic. Still very good though.

[i][b][h1]Gorgeous.[/h1][/b][/i]
Watching Supergiant Games's rise to indie darlinghood has been like watching a precocious child realize their full potential. Every one of their games attempts to break the mold in their own unique way while still carrying those Supergiant signature design choices, and this game is certainly no exception. Transistor embodies Supergiant's unique visual and auditory style almost excessively. Every aspect of this game just bleeds a sense of aestheticism unique to Supergiant art direction, from the character design to the environments to the lore to the UI. At pretty much every point in the game you are looking at something overall aesthetically appealing. Of course, all the flash can't make up for the rather large drawbacks that make this game less well-rounded than their other titles or other polished games; but the unique combat and visual/audio style define this as a must-play title for any fans of [b][i]Supergiant[/i], cyberpunk settings, modular spell systems, turn-based combat, female-protagonists, good music/ambiance[/b], or just [b]indie classics[/b] in general.


[h1][b]Pros: [/b][/h1]
+ pervasive sense of [b]aestheticism[/b] can be seen in every visual element in the game
+ fantastic [b]OST[/b] by Darren Korb feat. Ashley Barrett that the protag can hum along to at any point in the game
+ [b]modular combat system[/b]. each ability has an active form, passive form, or can modify other active abilities qualitatively, making for a very diverse (albeit finitely so) set of builds. the player can also switch to a hybrid turn-based system on a cooldown.
+ [b]maximization potential[/b]. there is a way to get maximum damage output and you are encouraged to achieve it, rather than it being artificially muddled by RNG or "equally viable" builds.


[h1][b]Cons: [/b][/h1]
- very [b]short[/b], and ironically [b]lacks replayability[/b] despite having a thematic focus on recursion. the story combat does not change and there is a limited number of combat challenges that are done when they are done, on an independent timeline of how often you complete the story. 
- [b]combat potential overshadows its necessity.[/b] this is the same problem Pokemon suffers: it created a much more expansive combat system than the actual game requires, creating this pervasive feeling of [i]"I could be doing more."[/i]. easy and accessible shouldn't translate to [b]wasted potential[/b]. i think i spent more time in the ability customization screen than actually using those abilities.
- [b]unsatisfactory writing[/b] / drawn-out storytelling with little payoff. the pacing of the story is definitely too slow for what it ultimately reveals, which isn't as noticeable until the second playthrough (which comes unfortunately quickly)
- [b]deep lore has little draw.[/b] the character blurbs that get unlocked with the abilities are nice, but there is little connection between this fictional character that doesn't exist anymore and can't be interacted with to the ability it is connected to.


It's usually a very good sign when the only drawback of a game is that there isn't enough of it, but in this case the pervasive feeling of this game not having enough of itself for itself actually hampers the experience. I wanted to see more of the characters moving, more in-game use of the music and Red's voice, more intense combat challenges, and more interaction with the environment. There's so many diverse tilesets being used and yet not enough battles to use them for. They definitely could have drawn this game out with more of itself and it wouldn't even seem diluted like it would for a standard grindy JRPG. This game honestly feels like Supergiant had a very set idea for the look, setting, and combat but figured they'd fill in the story later. It's still a fantastic experience and one of my favorite games, but it doesn't pull itself together enough to be a well-rounded experience. 

Visuals: +++
Combat: +++
Audio: ++
Feeling of Power: +
Feeling of Significance: -
Story: --

Overall: [b][h1]B+[/h1][/b]

Overall, I'd recommend this game to those who haven't played a real-time with pause CRPG. However, if you're familiar with the genre already, I think you'll find this game boring. If you have played Bastion (their first published game), it doesn't automatically mean that you'll enjoy this one, since the settings and gameplay are quite different. Now some details:

The story: Content wise it's nothing special or new, though the setting makes it enjoyable and entertaining for sure. But in general the stories in games suffer a lack of substance, so I suppose this isn't a particularly weak point for this game. I suppose for a kid the story would still be interesting. But for someone who is fairly well-read, these stories are just regurgitated material from age old themes, repackaged and watered down.  

Setting: The theme is sci-fi with a touch of romance. I think the screenshots and trailer do a better job at telling you about this than mere words.

Combat: Realtime with pause. Nothing new. Although I appreciate the streamlining, which allows for a very smooth gamepad experience. It does get repetitive at times, and at times I find myself playing only because I'm trying to finish the game, rather than enjoying the gameplay. 

Character skill system: Quite simple. You have a fixed set of skills that you can use and combine for certain effects. However, some skills and combinations are obviously far more useful than others. It's not balanced, and in particular, it's not designed to be played with your custom style. But then again, this isn't a substantial RPG in any way. So don't expect it to give you that. 

General system: the waypoint system is often just tedious. It doesn't add anything other than acting against the very streamlining of the game, which is supposed to be the appeal of this game. It's a short game, no need to be pretentious with the fake sophistry. 

Visuals: The best part about this game. The art style suits the game well, But this is subjective. In general, I like the studio's visual choices. 

Music: All right, nothing special. You might like it though if you're not a fanatic about music. 

Replayability: None. As I said, you'll find it already repetitive on the first play through.

Achievements: Grind fest. If you're a completionist, you won't enjoy this game. As I have already noted, the game has no replayability. I find games that have poor replayability yet makes you replay the game for achievements obnoxious. For this reason alone I would thumbs down the game. However, that's not to say I wouldn't recommend it to those who don't care about Steam achievements. 

Final verdict: Short casual gamepad game with a smooth and enjoyable gameplay, though quite flawed in many aspects.The lack of replayability and the requirement of grinding for achievements is disgusting, but beside the point.

[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Transistor is a part action RPG, part strategic planning game developed by  Supergiant Games and released in 2014. Lately when talking about different styles of games, I've used Supergiant as the example for "Having a self contained video game experience", where you play a game for 6-8 hours, finish it, and then think about and remember what you've experienced. It's a rare experience in the video game industry actually.

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] You start the game being dropped right into the middle of the story. You've got this talking-green-sword-thing called the "transistor", and you play as a mute-lady named "Red", who used to be a singer but has had her voice stolen.

There's a lot of open-endedness left to the player's interpretation actually... it all takes place in a futuristic sci-fi city which is slowly being corrupted by something known as the "Process".

Honestly the less you know about the story going into Transistor the more you'll probably enjoy it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2476386495

[b]Gameplay:[/b] The gameplay is unique. You unlock moves known as "Functions" which seem to reference programming, like Crash(), Breach(), etc. Those functions can be used in three different ways: As an active attack/ability, as an upgrade to another active-function (thereby giving it a unique upgrade), or as a passive upgrade to your character.

The interesting part about Transistors gameplay is mixing and matching different Functions. One of my favorites to use early on was Spark() as active, and upgraded with Crash() and Breach().
The idea is: You learn what a Function does, and then apply it to another function to make creative combo moves together. It took me several hours to get the hang of it, and even then once a new function was added I was slow to actually learn the new function.

By the end of the game you should have a pretty solid idea what you're doing, but even then you have a New Game + feature where you can replay while retaining your levels and unlocked moves.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2477399170

There's one more key gameplay mechanic which deserves recognition, at any point during combat you can take a "Turn()", which essentially pauses the game, and lets you map out a sequence of limited functions.

Sometimes I could get through a fight without using Turn(), because once you finish your turn you're vulnerable and can't attack until a cool down finishes where you can take a turn again.

It might sound kind of weird, and it definitely was another learning curve for me, but all of these little differences are what created an unforgettable video game experience.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Speaking of unforgettable experience. How about that ending? Someone came into my apartment and chopped a truck full of onions.

Again, Supergiant Games is one of my all time favorite developers because their games are so creative and inspiring. The visuals in Transistor are stunning and colorful. The Music itself is worth the purchase; I'd be tempted to just let the game idle to use my computer as a jukebox.

Bastion, Pyre, Transistor, each one fantastic and worth checking out and playing on any platform you prefer... There remains but one Supergiant game I haven't played yet: Hades. [i](I'm sure it'll be great too)[/i]

https://youtu.be/ljHXVv8lBMI

Greetings as I hope all is well! Below is my Steam Review for Transistor, thanks for reading as I wish you well in all your gaming adventures...

STORY/LORE - 9/10

The story hooks you right in when it comes to Transistor and it’s something that develops as you progress through the game. I wish there was a bit more of an expanded tutorial at first as the game can get a bit complicated in the beginning but you’ll pick things up after the first few levels. The overall story between Red, the Transistor, and the various enemies/bosses you’ll face is brilliantly done. 

Transistor is one of those games that you’ll never forget after you finish, it’s that epic. Also, please keep in mind, this is a very short game and one you can probably beat over a long night of gaming or during a weekend.

GAMEPLAY - 9/10

Once you get used to all the different abilities and general gameplay of what Transistor is all about, it ends up being pretty fun. The way you can mix and match main abilities with other abilities is very well done which opens up a lot of replayability. Timing is everything and being able to pause time to deliver whatever attacks and combos you want is fun once you get the hang of it.

You can replay this game in various different ways and have a completely new experience depending on what you want to try out each time. There are a ton of combinations to use based on your playstyle and that’s another great aspect of Transistor to try and beat the game in other ways. It’s also a lot of fun mixing and matching different abilities if you’re into doing multiple playthroughs of Transistor.

GRAPHICS - 10/10

The graphics of Transistor are absolutely amazing! Considering this game was made back in 2014, it still holds up incredibly well to this very day. Seeing all the innovatively designed levels and areas in the game and how fluid everything was truly makes Transistor shine.
 
It’s also pretty visually amazing when you hold TAB and see Red humming in all these different levels which amplifies the lighting, music, and tone. Supergiant Games know how to make beautiful looking video games, I can tell you that after playing Bastion and working through their other titles.

SOUNDTRACK - 10/10

The overall soundtrack of Transistor truly makes it stand out and has become a staple these days of Supergiant Games. It reminds me of being in a local Manhattan cafe in New York City where you sit back and enjoy some incredible music that touches on many awesome genres. 

Each level has a unique soundtrack to it and there even is a level where you can change up the music to listen as you go through various challenges. It’s just all really well done and undoubtedly leaves a lasting impression once you beat it.

MULTIPLAYER - N/A

There is no multiplayer aspect to Transistor as it’s not really needed. This is a single player game as there is no point to add multiplayer. If anything, after you beat the game, you can replay the game again with the abilities you’ve earned in your first playthrough. You can continue leveling up, earn more abilities, and more in the Recurse mode.

FINAL SCORE - 9/10

Overall, Transistor is a great game. It’s short, sweet, and to the point. The graphics are amazing and the soundtrack truly adds a uniqueness in the game that you’ll remember for years to come. The story is a fantastic one and without getting into too many details to ruin anything, will be one that you’ll enjoy as you continue playing.

There is some good replayability to Transistor if you want to get multiple playthroughs in for more Steam Achievements to experience the game using more combinations of abilities. Transistor is a unique sci-fi kind of game that is just one of those “must play” titles you need to experience at least once in your gaming life. What are you waiting for? Red needs your help!

88942876.review:
[h3]A bizarre, mysterious, yet enthralling action RPG.[/h3]
Transistor's distinctive combat mechanics are perfectly complemented with a moving and mysterious story - and the game never ceases to amaze with its vibrant artwork and beautiful soundtrack.

The stunning hand-drawn "cutscenes" service the story without overstaying their welcome. The soundtrack encompasses a variety of moody cyberpunk tones as well as more lighthearted, upbeat tracks, and the detailed artwork mixes perfectly with the sound design to make for a consistently atmospheric experience.

The odd, yet exciting narrative has the dramatic undertones of an emotional love story and the style of a streamlined action game. And as a side note about the story: I love the symbolism of Red's voice and how it ties into both the game's artistic direction (with the soundtrack and narration) and the subtle, yet effective message about political corruption and the voice of the people.

[h3]Transistor is every bit as unique mechanically as it is artistically.[/h3]
The combat is built around the Turn() mechanic, which combines real-time action with time slowdown segments reminiscent of turn-based combat. It's strategic, streamlined, and satisfying, with very little waiting or guesswork.

The game also has a unique "Function" system where any unlocked ability can be used actively in combat, as an upgrade to another ability, or passively to grant boosts to the player. (Notes about ingame characters are tied to these Functions, and these notes are unlocked as different functions are used - encouraging the player to experiment with their loadout.)

Plus, Transistor has some fantastic balancing mechanics for its combat that I haven't seen in other games of its kind. For example - losing all your health doesn't instantly kill the player and send them back to the last checkpoint - rather, it overloads and disables the player's most upgraded ability, which decreases the pool of available functions for a short time.

[h3]Overall...[/h3]
There isn't much for me to criticize about Transistor. The linear design is sometimes brought off track by less important story beats (like the OVC terminals that don't really do anything). The enemy design for the main "Process" robots that are fought throughout the game are relatively unimpressive compared to the artwork and sprites for everything else. And the narration, while well-acted and vital to the story, goes off on some unnecessary tangents.  But overall, I think Transistor is a fantastic action RPG that's every bit as emotionally moving as it is streamlined and fun. 8/10

88326743.review:
When Everything Changes, Nothing Changes

After Bastion brought Supergiant Games into public eye, instead of trying to rehash what they did before, Supergiant went for something completely different. From rugged, wild west inspired setting and action RPG, to slick, urban aesthetic and gameplay style is a unique mix of real-time combat with pause and action RPG. But did it manage to best Bastion?

The presentation is striking visually,with fantastic artworks and art direction by Jen Zee. All characters have fantastic designs and stand out from another easily. The urban setting has a jazzy, sleek look to it and fits the atmosphere perfectly. It's a clear step up from Bastion with its simple art style. Audio-wise, the soundtrack was made to reflect visuals, with more
electronic music as well as more vocal tracks, such as "Paper Boats" or "We All Become". This time around it's the sound that's less to my taste, especially the combat music is much weaker. Logan was reduced to smaller role this time around, while still good, it's not as good as The Narrator in Bastion.

This time, Logan voices The Transistor, or rather, the lover of Red trapped inside the titular sword. After one of her musical performances, Red was attacked and barely escaped alive thanks to her lover. You play as Red, going after the people who made attempt at her life, making it clear she wasn't the first person that was targeted this way and getting mixed in the fate of the City. Story itself is more abstract, more metaphorical than Bastion and it deals with the dangers of democracy in ultimately humane way. And it's more of a downer, really, not reaching the heights of Bastion.

Gameplay is where it gets truly unique. Your sword Transistor supports 4 functions, which can be further modified with other functions to amplify or change how they work. How many functions you can have at once is limited by the Memory stat, which you gain as you level up. You can play the combat in real-time, but it's rather clunky and far from optimal. Then you also have the "Turn phase", which allows you to plan your actions in quick succession, allowing for much more damage. 

But the issue is, after using your turn, you can't attack or use your abilities other than invisibility and similar. So you get this weird gap in the flow, where all you can do is just run around, waiting for turn bar to refill, allowing you to use turn or attack in real time again. Which is the crux of the issue, that while this sounds interesting, it's interesting only on paper. It's not so much fun to play. This weird gameplay flow gets tiring even before you finish the game, and that should take you 3 or 4 hours. That might be partially caused by the levels all looking almost identical, it looks good, but blends together.

Bottom line is, that while Transistor is still a good(/decent) game and has some fresh ideas, the execution in certainly lacking in some aspects. It's clear though that developers do clearly care and are passionate about making games, as well as the game having higher budget, but I don't think this one panned out that well.
Nonetheless, I think it's still worth playing if for nothing else than for trying to do something different. The Noclip documentary is must as well.

Gameplay and story-wise, Transistor is confused and boring. All it has going for it is some nice songs.

Attempting to mesh hack-and-slash gameplay with turn based strategy is a concept that might work. But it doesn't here, first and foremost because using the pause function to plan your next move stops you from instantly returning to the realtime action because your abilities are prevented from working for a cooldown. Meanwhile, you lack any good mobility. Balance and difficulty aside, this creates a very disjointed flow.

The various abilities you can unlock don't feel like they do anything to help your options - everything feels very similar as you just try to optimise your damage during the frozen time, before helplessly running from whatever enemies remain. You don't have to worry about being damaged during the turn, so basically the game can't help but be easy. There are some extra mechanics to think about, but overall nothing that impacts gameplay significantly. Also, some abilities don't always meet their planned mark because enemies move slightly, almost unpredictably, when you execute your turn.

Finally, the story is some generic edgy dystopian ASMR clown festival. Kind of appealing sounding, but it's just slow and obvious and it really needed more world development to make the ending anywhere close to even acceptable, let alone good. Then again, for a 4-5 hour main line, what it managed to do story-wise is pretty impressive.

And it looks decent, and sounds even better. It's just a shame the actual game flows too poorly to be worthwhile.

[h1]“We are paper boats floating on a stream
And it would seem
We'll never be apart ”   
[i]~Darren Korb, Paper Boats[/i][/h1]

Welcome back... to the dreamlike world... of [b]Supergiant Games[/b]. In my [b]Bastion[/b] review I've already explained why these guys are my most favorite video game developers in the entire world. Feel free to check it for more details, but long story short, these people? They treat their games like an art. So, what we get from them is... absolutely unique and beautiful. Every single time it's a unique experience. The one that stays with you. Forever. An experience that includes some unique gameplay elements, godlike narration, fantastic music and the atmosphere that can and [i]will[/i] make you cry from how beautiful and sad it is. So... yeah. Here's their second game. And it's called [b]Transistor[/b].

[b]Supergiant[/b]'s first project, [b]Bastion[/b], turned out to be a big success. It wasn't the biggest or most complicated game out there. But when people dived into the dreamlike world of ruined [b]Caelondia[/b]? [b]Logan Cunningham[/b]'s narration and [b]Darren Korb[/b]'s soundtrack instantly swept them away. And when you “woke up” from that beautiful dream? You were like “That... was... [i]awesome![/i] I want more!”. But here's a thing about [b]Supergiant[/b] – they don't do sequels. Or prequels. Or spin-offs. Every one of their games is complete piece of art. So, first thing first, [i]do not[/i] expect [b]Bastion 2[/b] here. Even though ruined city of [b]Cloudbank[/b] do feel a little bit like [b]Caelondia[/b] and you sure will notice some similar motifs here, it's a completely different game. But obviously, gameplay is not the most important thing here. It's pretty awesome, but we'll return to it a little bit later. First, I want to talk about the most important thing in every [b]Supergiants[/b]' game – the atmosphere.

See, since pretty much every single [b]Bastion[/b] review praised [b]Darren Korb[/b]'s music and [b]Ashley Lynn Barrett[/b]'s singing, [b]Supergiant[/b] decided to focus on exactly that. [b]Transistor[/b]? It's all music. Our hero this time is a young singer who's called just [b]Red[/b]. And [b]Red[/b]... she just lost everything. She lost a person who was ready to sacrifice everything for her. And she lost the only thing that helped her to stay strong – her voice. They took everything from her. And now? Now it's time for them to pay for it. Ever thought what if [b]Quentin Tarantino[/b]'s [b]Kill Bill[/b] wasn't that cheesy and provoking... thing with tons of blood? Well, here's [b]Supergiant[/b]'s take on the concept. Like in [b]Bastion[/b], you instantly dive into that certain state of mind where it begins to feel a lot like lucid dream. And the attention to details? Dear Lord... For example, guess who voiced [b]Red[/b]? Yep,  it's [b]Ashley Lynn Barrett[/b]. The same [b]Ashley Lynn Barrett[/b] who voiced [b]Zia[/b] in [b]Bastion[/b] and performed pretty much every female vocals in soundtrack. And now... she's a broken character. With her voice trapped inside the mysterious sword called the [b]Transistor[/b]. Together with a soul of the person who wanted to be with her more than anything. He can still talk to her. It's just... she can't answer. All she can do is to hum her songs. And listen to the voice in her sword. Begging her not to go...

OK, I'll just stop here, since that's pretty much where our game begins, but seriously, [b]Supergiant[/b] did it again. [b]Transistor[/b]'s setting, writing and presentation? It's a bloody masterpiece. Just listening [b]Logan Cunningham[/b] (because yes, our narrator from [b]Bastion[/b] returned, only this time his narration would be even more heartbreaking since his character really, like, [i]really[/i] won't want [b]Red[/b] to do what she's about to do) talking to [b]Ashley Lynn[/b]... and her humming softly to the sky (most of the tracks in this game have humming versions because yes, [b]Ashley[/b]'s humming deserved to be included in soundtrack) with [b]Darren Korb[/b]'s music playing on background... it's just... I dunno, [i]I love[/i] this game. Even though every single game from [b]Supergiants[/b] is beautiful in its own way, this one? So far, it's the most romantic one. [b]Logan[/b]? [b]Ashley[/b]? [i]Bravo![/i] Just following you two for six hours? It felt absolutely beautiful.

Guess, it's time to talk a bit about the actual gameplay, right? I mean, we all know that [b]Supergiant[/b] can create the atmosphere. [i]The[/i] atmosphere. But how does this game actually plays? Well, like I already said, gameplay here is pretty great. Again, it's not the biggest thing out there, but core mechanics became way, [i]way[/i] more complicated. It's still an action [b]RPG[/b] kind of thing, only this time, it comes with... turn-based element. A bit like what we had in good ol' [b]Baldur's Gate[/b]. You know, that certain thing that allowed us to pause the game, give our characters their commands and then see things happening in real time again? That's pretty much it. Only here? It's more complicated than that. See, using such pause also brings some sort of grid to help you planning. And you [i]will[/i] want to plan. Because very often good planning will be your only way to survive, while bad one may lead to quick defeat, since using this feature will put all of your attacking powers on pretty long cooldown. You use tactical mode? Be ready to become helpless for some time. Sure, you can always spam your attacks in real-time, but like I said, good planning will often be your only way to win here. Just because otherwise you'll never be fast enough to outsmart your enemies and perform stuff like backstabbing. In other words, even though this game may look a lot like [b]Bastion[/b] on screenshots and there's even some sort of alternative to [b]Bastion[/b] itself, where you'll be able to do challenges, the core mechanics this time is way more tricky and will require some time to get used to.

Same goes to the skills. Every single skill in this game can be used as both main thing and enhancing modification. You select one skill to be used as an actual attack and then you select two other to modify it in different ways. It sounds pretty simple, but what you can actually achieve with that is absolutely incredible. Experimenting is very important in [b]Transistor[/b]. At some points of the game you'll be like “Wow, this game is [i]hard![/i]” And then you'll experiment a bit with what you already have and be like “Why didn't I do that hours ago?! I'm so strong now!”. Even though there isn't much stuff in this game, it's absolutely awesome what [b]Supergiant[/b] achieved with what they had. Which is also... pretty smart, really. I mean, with [b]Transistor[/b] being a game about sacrifices and treasuring what wasn't taken from you? Having gameplay to actually fit the moral of the story? Fantastic stuff...

So... yeah... You know how it is. [i]Of course[/i] I recommend this game. It's [b]Supergiant[/b] title. You see a game from these guys? You buy it. Complete bundle. With soundtrack. Because there's no other way. As long as you feel like there's a place in your heart for something more than just another empty online shooter? As long as you want to dive into something real? Something that matters? Something that can be considered as an art? Something [i]to remember?[/i] Don't you dare to miss this game. Like [b]Bastion[/b], it'll need you to be completely relaxed to properly enjoy it (because, like I said above, a [i]huge[/i] part of the game is in the atmosphere), but this time you should also be ready to explore the new mechanics. Which is way more complicated than it looks. You ready for that? The dark streets of [b]Cloudbank[/b] are waiting for you. Hello... [b]Red[/b]......

85895086.review:
„ The sky looks blue because we want it too” - Farrah Yon-Dale

tl;dr – Supergiant’s second game is definitely worth a try. Especially when it is on sale, because it’s quite short (but powerful) so it can be quite expensive with standard price when comparing time/price ratio. Brilliant soundtrack, interesting world (but quite hollow), charming story and characteristic art style of the developer will make you remember the game for long. 

Art: 
 The game is set in future-styled, world with heavy inspiration from art-deco and some minor cyber elements. This, with unique Supergiant’s geometric isometric brush, is making quite memorable visuals coherent to the topic and plot. 
Music composed by Darren Korb (he created OST for Bastion and Hades as well) was the first thing that caught my attention. Not only “Transistor’s” OST, but all developer’s games are polished in this area. Definitely helps with immersion. Main protagonist is a singer, which unluckily lost voice. We can although hear when she sings them via Ashley Lynn Barrett lungs. Those tracks ended in my top games’ music pieces playlist, simply because it left me awestruck. 
The plot is interesting, but I don’t want to make spoilers. All additional elements about the world are presented in small chunks like skills or difficulty modifiers descriptions and narrator throwing one or two sentences here and there. It is left for you to compile it into a unified story. When you are willing to drill into interpretations, game turns out to be a discussion about changes vs status quo in ever shape-shifting world. Additionally, you can develop bonds to the characters, so it can get very emotional later.

Gameplay:
I would say it is turn based roguelike, but it would not be a precise description. It has closed combat arenas when you traverse though story like in “Hades”, “Enter The Gungeon”, “The Binding of Isaac”, or other pure roguelikes. You can use your skills to make your way in similar manner, but later on it will be virtually impossible. From the second challenge you are given “turn()” ability to plan your actions in turn (something like Frozen Synapse, but when you are executing turn enemies are standing still). New abilities are adding new possibilities to play with, so you won’t be bored though all the playthrough. Game incentivize you with changing active skills by showing you additional chunks of history. 
It is quite an easy game when played purely without modifiers. It’s getting more interesting when you master the mechanics and recurse though the story in new game+ mode and adding so-called limiters. There are as well challenges, but they gave me minor troubles. There is interesting mechanics twist in the last enemy (because there are no bosses in traditional meaning), but I wouldn’t spoil it for you.

Overall:
For me, it was a nice, interesting title. Even though it is quite short, it’s well polished in any aspect and deserves more attention. I haven’t played Bastion, and Hades yet, but this game is living in their shadow which is quite upsetting, because it was one of the best games played by me in some categories. When you’re less into action (which later can be pretty intense) but more into story, and have some spare money I would definitely recommend it. 

7.5/10
~adiabat

84408263.review:
Bastion and Hades by Supergiant are two amazing games full of personality, love and - most importantly - fun gameplay. Transistor is, in comparison to those games, underwhelming.

As usual with Supergiant, the art is great, the music is fantastic and the voice acting is a pleasure to listen to. Everything else in Transistor, however, is a pain. The entire game is painfully linear, the lore and story are vague at best and confusing at worst, and the ending of the game is an absolute insult. The worst part, however, is the gameplay which is so bad that words could not possibly describe it.

The gameplay, aside from walking, consists of fighting enemies from the process in a hybrid of real time and turn battles. You have two choices; attack enemies in real time with attacks while youre stuck in the same animation over and over and enemies can freely attack you without penalty, or activate the turn mode where you can walk around and plan moves. The real time mode is incredibly frustrating because of the animation lock that many moves have, and the turn mode is blatantly overpowered. The devs realized this, probably, because after every turn action, you have to wait a good 5 seconds  before you can attack (or just use the turn mode) again. In those 5 seconds, you are defenseless aside from the dash, if you even chose that as an attack.

The battles that result from this are so incredibly janky that I find it hard to believe that someone looked at this and said "yeah, this is good" and it might be one of the worst battle systems I have ever seen in a game. Neither "mode" really feels satisfying and some of the later battles have some of the most frustrating enemies ever, that are just permanently invisible and can kill you in two hits. Why? Did no one test this battle system at all? Its not even hard, really, its just frustrating because you constantly fight the jank and not the enemies.

So what Transistor is, essentially, is walk through linear world (with good art, mind you), fight, walk again, fight, walk again. The story has an extremely slow buildup and never truly gets good, and the ending that you get is just an insult after everything you went through. From Supergiant I expect quality and seeing how good Hades is and Bastion was, it just confuses me that Transistor is this janky and rough. I guess a miss is allowed, though - and luckily it isnt too long. Sadly, I cant recommend it to anyone and the many positive reviews kind of baffle me.

The art is beautiful, and the story is good - but there really isn't much to encourage a repeat visit, even the achievements for completing New Game+. Undoubtedly worth a look if you're into sci-fi stories and art-focused games.

83996695.review:
Play as a mute singer who'd rather let her sword boyfriend "Persuade" the computers into leaving them alone.

Weird hook, great story.
This is one of the scarce examples of utopia done right, many stories favor dystopia because in an utopic world is incredibly difficult to follow struggles of their characters since the word itself means that a world doesn't have such problems.
Art, expression, striving to be better are what push people into doing what they do and ending up feeling incomplete when their craft is not apreciated enough, so you can still have misery in a technically perfect world, and the story only takes off from here.
Gameplay is a strange one, think of your sword more like an oversized magic wand rather than a melee weapon, all attacks have this strange windup to it that unfortunately have the consequence of stopping you dead on your tracks.
The two most innovatives part of the gameplay are the modular attack system and the turn time.
Modular attacks means that every attack is itself a module and can be used as a base or as a modified for others attacks to use: want a minigun? take a long range weak shot with low cost and add a speed modifier and a piercing modifier; what about a mortar? Add the delayed explosiuon and aoe attack onto a long ranged attack; the possibilities are endless.
The turn time is more simple to grasp, hitting a button you will stop time and plan out your actions to execute, each one of them taking some time out of a bar that needs recharging once used, this element could have been used better since you cannot attack once used.
Art, Music and composition are stellar as expected from Supergiant Games and some of the best you'll find.

Gameplaywise could be better, but the deal is sealed by everything else, an extremely solid title and one you should get.
